ã“ã‚“ã«ã¡ã¯ã€å¯Œå£«æ¦®ã§ã™ã€‚ æ˜æ—¥ã‹ã‚‰SIDI Hubãƒ¯ã‚·ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒ³D.C.ä¼šåˆã ã¨ã„ã†ã®ã«ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã¾ã§ã—ã‹ç´¹ä»‹ã§ãã¾ã›ã‚“ã§ã—ãŸã€‚ãƒ™ãƒ«ãƒªãƒ³ä¼šåˆã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚‚é †æ¬¡èª­ã‚“ã§ã„ã“ã†ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ãŒã€ä»Šå›ã§ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚‚çµ‚ã‚ã‚Šã§ã™ã®ã§ã€ã¾ãšã¯ã“ã“ã¾ã§ã€‚ åŒã˜ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°ã§Alan Turing InstituteãŒã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ã§é–‹å‚¬ã—ãŸã€ŒInternational Conference on Trustworthy Digital Infrastructure 2024ã€ã¨ã®ã‚¸ãƒ§ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ãŒSIDI Hubã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ä¼šåˆã®æœ€å¾Œã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒ ã§ã™ã€‚ International Conference on Trustworthy Digital Infrastructure 2024 https://www.turing.ac.uk/events/international

ã“ã‚“ã«ã¡ã¯ã€å¯Œå£«æ¦®ã§ã™ã€‚

æ˜æ—¥ã‹ã‚‰SIDI Hubãƒ¯ã‚·ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒ³D.C.ä¼šåˆã ã¨ã„ã†ã®ã«ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã¾ã§ã—ã‹ç´¹ä»‹ã§ãã¾ã›ã‚“ã§ã—ãŸã€‚ãƒ™ãƒ«ãƒªãƒ³ä¼šåˆã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚‚é †æ¬¡èª­ã‚“ã§ã„ã“ã†ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ãŒã€ä»Šå›ã§ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚‚çµ‚ã‚ã‚Šã§ã™ã®ã§ã€ã¾ãšã¯ã“ã“ã¾ã§ã€‚


åŒã˜ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒŸãƒ³ã‚°ã§Alan Turing InstituteãŒã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ã§é–‹å‚¬ã—ãŸã€ŒInternational Conference on Trustworthy Digital Infrastructure 2024ã€ã¨ã®ã‚¸ãƒ§ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ãŒSIDI Hubã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ä¼šåˆã®æœ€å¾Œã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒ ã§ã™ã€‚

International Conference on Trustworthy Digital Infrastructure 2024
https://www.turing.ac.uk/events/international-conference-trustworthy-digital-infrastructure-2024
Alan Turingã¨ã„ãˆã°ã‚¨ãƒ‹ã‚°ãƒæš—å·ã®è§£èª­ã«æˆåŠŸã—ãŸã‚¤ã‚®ãƒªã‚¹ã®æ•°å­¦è€…ã§ã™ã­ã€‚ç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡ä¸–ç•Œå¤§æˆ¦ä¸­ã«ãƒ‰ã‚¤ãƒ„ã®Uãƒœãƒ¼ãƒˆã®æš—å·é€šä¿¡ã®è§£èª­ã‚’è¡Œã†ã“ã¨ã§é€£åˆå›½ãŒæ¢è»¸å›½ã«å¯¾ã™ã‚‹å‹åˆ©ã‚’åã‚ã‚‹ã®ã‚’æ—©ã‚ãŸã€ã¨è¨€ã‚ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹äººã§ã™ã€‚ã„ã‚ã‚†ã‚‹ãƒãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ãƒã‚·ãƒ³ã¨ã‹ãƒãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã®äººã§ã™ã­ã€‚
Alan Turing Instituteã®ã‚¤ãƒ™ãƒ³ãƒˆã§ã¯ã€ä»¥ä¸‹ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªãƒˆãƒ”ãƒƒã‚¯ãŒå–ã‚Šä¸Šã’ã‚‰ã‚ŒãŸã‚ˆã†ã§ã™ã€‚ ã‚ˆã‚Šå®‰å…¨ãªãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«å…¬å…±ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ© ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆ-EUã®åˆ¶åº¦ã¨æ¯”è¼ƒã€å­ä¾›ã®ç™»éŒ² ã‚±ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹ãƒŒãƒ“ã‚¢äººã®æ¨©åˆ© ãƒ‰ã‚¤ãƒ„é–‹ç™ºåºï¼šã‚¢ãƒ•ãƒªã‚«ã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹ãƒã‚¤ãƒ†ã‚¯æŠ€è¡“ã®ãŸã‚ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã‚¢ãƒ¼ã‚­ãƒ†ã‚¯ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¼ã®å†è€ƒ ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDã®DNAï¼šãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã‚’è¶…ãˆã¦ ä¸­å›½ã®åŒ»ç™‚ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹ä¿¡é ¼ã®å½¹å‰² ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«åŸºç›¤IDã®ãŸã‚ã®LLM åˆ†æ•£å‹ã‚¨ã‚³ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã®ãŸã‚ã®ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆå®Ÿè£…ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ« åŠ´åƒè€…ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©LLM è‹±å›½AIå®‰å…¨ç ”ç©¶æ‰€ã¯LLMã®ä¿¡é ¼ã‚¹ã‚³ã‚¢ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚’ä½œæˆ å‡ºæ‰€ã‚’æ±ºå®šã™ã‚‹ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDæ¨™æº–ã®å½¹å‰²ã«é–¢ã™ã‚‹è­°è«–

SIDI Hubã¯Alan Turing Instituteã¨ã®å”æ¥­é–¢ä¿‚ã‚’ç¯‰ããŸã‚ã®æ–¹æ³•ã«ã¤ã„ã¦è­°è«–ãƒ»æ¤œè¨ãŒè¡Œã‚ã‚ŒãŸã¨ã®ã“ã¨ã§ã™ã€‚ã“ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«ã‚¢ã‚«ãƒ‡ãƒŸã‚¢ã¨ã®ã¤ãªãŒã‚Šã‚’ç¯‰ãã®ã¯ã¨ã¦ã‚‚å¤§åˆ‡ãªã“ã¨ã§ã™ã­ã€‚ ä»–ã«ã‚‚SIDI Hubã¨ã‚¢ã‚«ãƒ‡ãƒŸã‚¢ã¨ã®ã¤ãªãŒã‚Šã¨ã—ã¦ã¯ã“ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªã‚‚ã®ãŒæŒ™ã’ã‚‰ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚
ãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒã‚·ãƒ¼é ˜åŸŸ ãƒãƒ«ã‚¦ã‚§ãƒ¼ç§‘å­¦æŠ€è¡“å¤§å­¦ ã‚¸ãƒ§ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³å¤§å­¦ ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒã‚®ãƒ¼ãƒ¡ãƒ­ãƒ³å¤§å­¦ ã‚»ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£é ˜åŸŸ ã‚·ãƒ¥ãƒˆã‚¥ãƒƒãƒˆã‚¬ãƒ«ãƒˆå¤§å­¦ ãƒãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒªãƒ³ã‚° NIST è‹±å›½ã®å¤§å­¦ ãã®ä»– ISOC/U WITWATERSRANDå¤§å­¦ ãªã© ã¾ã ã¾ã ã‚¢ã‚«ãƒ‡ãƒŸã‚¢ã¨å”æ¥­ãŒæ·±ã‚ã‚‰ã‚Œã‚‹é ˜åŸŸã¯è‰²ã€…ã¨ã‚ã‚Šãã†ã€ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã§è­°è«–ãŒé‡ã­ã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
æš—å·åˆ†é‡ãªã©ã‚¢ã‚«ãƒ‡ãƒŸã‚¢ãŒæœãŸã™å½¹å‰²ã¯å¤§ãã„ä¸€æ–¹ã§ã€ã¾ã ã¾ã ç”£æ¥­ç•Œã¨ã®ã‚®ãƒ£ãƒƒãƒ—ã¯å¤§ãã„ã£ã¦ã“ã¨ã§ã™ã­ã€‚


ã‚®ãƒ£ãƒƒãƒ—ã‚’åŸ‹ã‚ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«è‰²ã€…ã¨ã‚³ãƒ©ãƒœãƒ¬ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’é€²ã‚ã¦ã„ãã“ã¨ã«ãªã‚‹ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ å®Ÿéš›SIDI Hubã®ã‚¤ãƒ™ãƒ³ãƒˆã¯æ¯å›ã‚¢ã‚«ãƒ‡ãƒŸã‚¢ã‹ã‚‰ã‚‚å‚åŠ è€…ã‚’æ‹›å¾…ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚


ã¨ã€ã„ã†ã¨ã“ã‚ã§ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚‚çµ‚ã‚ã‚Šã§ã™ã€‚ æ˜æ—¥ã¯ãƒ¯ã‚·ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒ³D.C.ã§ã®ä¼šåˆã§ã™ã€‚æ™‚å·®ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã®ã§ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ãã‚‹ã®ã¯æ—¥æœ¬æ™‚é–“ã§ã¯æ˜å¾Œæ—¥ã«ãªã‚‹ã®ã‹ãªã€‚

WerdmÃ¼ller on Medium

A conversation with myself about immigration

What is your ideal place? What are its values? Continue reading on Medium Â»

What is your ideal place? What are its values?

Continue reading on Medium Â»

15:45 • 17 days ago

Ben WerdmÃ¼ller

A conversation with myself about immigration

What is your ideal place to live? I grew up in Oxford, England, which has radically colored my view of what a home can look like. Itâ€™s hardly a city at all â€” one girlfriend derisively called it â€œa villageâ€ â€” but sits close enough to London that you can get there in under an hour. Itâ€™s surrounded by green space. The city itself is home one of the oldest universities in the world, around which

What is your ideal place to live?

I grew up in Oxford, England, which has radically colored my view of what a home can look like. Itâ€™s hardly a city at all â€” one girlfriend derisively called it â€œa villageâ€ â€” but sits close enough to London that you can get there in under an hour. Itâ€™s surrounded by green space.

The city itself is home one of the oldest universities in the world, around which other prominent universities, learning institutions, NGOs, and businesses have sprung up. The result is that the place is filled with bookstores, music, theater, art and culture, but even more importantly, there is a constant influx of people from all over the world: not as tourists, but as temporary residents. This diverse population has brought new ideas, cultures, cuisines, and ways of living. Being from somewhere else is completely normal.

You donâ€™t need a car to get around. Thereâ€™s adequate public transit (even if itâ€™s getting more expensive), but itâ€™s also incredibly walkable. Bicycle paths are everywhere, and arguably bicycles are the easiest, fastest way to get around.

Being a university town, ideas are important. Assuming they are delivered in good faith and are well-considered, diverse ideas are considered seriously. There is little dogma beyond the idea of the university itself. There are certainly no established lines that you need to arrange yourself behind.

Most of these things are true in London, too, of course, and Iâ€™ve more recently found it in cities like New York and San Francisco. New York in particular has become one of my favorite places in the world: a space where all kinds of people literally live on top of each other. Itâ€™s a vibrant space where everything feels possible, while also being one of the safest, most walkable cities in the world (with a surprising amount of green space). I donâ€™t think Iâ€™d risk cycling around it, but people certainly do.

There are a few things that make these spaces great: green spaces, walkability, public transit. But I think the most important is their diversity, and therefore their openness to immigration and different ways of being.

The inverse describes places I donâ€™t want to live in: car-driven spaces where people generally have the same shared heritage and the same ideas, with little public transit and low connections to the outside world.

So youâ€™re pro-immigration?

I am, but I think of immigration as a means to an end. Iâ€™m not as much pro-immigration as I am anti-monoculture. The goal isnâ€™t to have lots of immigrants in itself; the goal is to have a broad, inclusive society, which implies a vibrancy, and in turn requires different cultures, ideas, and ways of living to present themselves.

Thereâ€™s plenty of research that shows how beneficial this can be: it pushes up wages and economic activity, and particularly for populations that are becoming older on average (thatâ€™s us), provides younger workers.

Selfishly, itâ€™s also more comfortable for me. I donâ€™t like monocultures in part because I am never part of one: as a third culture kid with parents who have different nationalities and grew up in a third place, I canâ€™t be by definition. As well as white American and Northern European, my heritage is Jewish and Indonesian. Monocultures necessarily exclude me, and I donâ€™t feel safe in them; they make me feel like an Other.

While middle class residents see a net gain, there is a growing body of evidence which may show that immigration can harm working class populations in a host location by displacing them from work and affecting their wages. That canâ€™t be overlooked, and questions need to be asked about how they can see a net gain too. I think the solution relates to funneling more of the net gains from increased economic activity into better social programs, free education, and better social infrastructure overall.

I donâ€™t think the goal can be to preserve monocultures. Communities do gain overall if there is immigration. Those communities are qualitatively better places to live as well as statistically more prosperous. And itâ€™s simply not where the world is headed: global transit and communications are cheaper and more available than ever. Even if we all decided we hated immigration and wanted to be inward-facing societies forever, the cat is out of the bag. Instead, then, we need to make sure everyone sees the benefit from it.

So youâ€™re a socialist?

It depends on your definition! I think thereâ€™s a lot to be gained from social infrastructure: public healthcare, education, and transit, social programs like welfare, and ways to life people up who fall through the cracks.

Knowing that low-income people may not always see the benefit from immigration, I think we need to provide stronger structures to lift everyone up, which include universal healthcare, accessible, high-quality education, and reliable, frequent public transit. We can fund those through stronger taxes for the wealthiest in our society (many of whom are also in favor of this), by collecting taxes from people and businesses who already owe but donâ€™t pay, as well as efficiency gains in how we provide existing services. Thereâ€™s been plenty of work to show that the numbers do add up and these are perfectly possible things to provide.

But if youâ€™re asking me if I believe in fully centrally-planned economies? No. Everyone should be able to start a business or work for themselves, and I donâ€™t think government is best placed to innovate.

What about crime?

Most violent crime is caused by poverty, and migrants are statistically much less likely to commit it. The stereotype of immigrant populations coming in and ruining the place is a racist myth, and increasing the base quality of life for everyone through better social infrastructure will reduce crime. Take San Francisco: although crime in the city is generally overstated by the right-wing press, a radically widened divide between rich and poor has resulted in more car break-ins, shoplifting, and similar offenses. Those are not things that would happen in a city where everyone was able to live comfortably.

The most egregious crimes are white collar, where financial losses are significant. Preventing these and effectively collecting taxes from people who should be contributing will help provide for the people who are truly feeling the squeeze.

Clearly, in any given society, there need to be sensible laws and enforcement of them. The biggest gains, though, are not created through draconian policing. They come from stronger social infrastructure that genuinely protects people. If people cannot afford to live, they will do what they need to in order to survive. Where this has to do with immigration â€” potentially at low income levels â€” more help must be provided.

What about refugees?

Europe in particular has received an influx of refugees because of ongoing wars. That canâ€™t be an externality: if you fund a war, taking on refugees from that war is a reasonable thing to expect. Thatâ€™s not a comment on whether those wars are right or wrong; itâ€™s simply an inevitability.

Meanwhile, countries like Britain that spent centuries invading the rest of the world, often oppressing them violently, are now complaining about immigration and refugees. All Iâ€™ll say about that is that the world is interconnected: actions have consequences.

And that interconnectedness goes further. Our actions and inaction with respect to global trade and the effects of the climate crisis are also creating refugees. Weâ€™re all implicated, and of course we should have a duty to deal with the human consequences. Not only that, but I would argue we have a fundamental duty to help other human beings â€” while accepting that not everyone agrees. Like so much else in this conversation, it comes down to our values and priorities.

What if I like living in a monoculture?

You do you! Monocultures will always available. Iâ€™m just not interested in living in one, and the evidence shows that they will always be poorer than open, inclusive societies. I think people who vote for them thinking that it will lead to a better life for them are unfortunately mistaken.

The country where I grew up voted to legally prevent me from living there again in a referendum in 2016. It has proven to be an economic and cultural shot in the foot: Brexit was a disaster, and only 31% of Britons now say they were right to leave the EU.

Also, seeing seas of Trump supporters at conventions holding up signs saying â€œmass deportations nowâ€ is pretty chilling. Qualitatively, that mindset â€” only people like us are allowed! â€” is something I truly fear, not least because that always means that people like me are never allowed. Thatâ€™s taken us to some dark places in the past, but itâ€™s also simply not a recipe for a nice place to live.

So youâ€™re playing the Nazi card?

A lot of people call people Nazis these days. In itself itâ€™s become a clichÃ© that can be a barrier to further discussion. I do tend to agree with Mike Godwin, the author of Godwinâ€™s Law, who said that it does not apply to describing Trump. But I get that people are easily triggered by it.

I think thereâ€™s always, by definition, a kind of fascism inherent in wanting to live in a monoculture. Fascism deals with in-groups and out-groups; similarly, monocultures, by definition, need to maintain conformity. Itâ€™s not that people in those places are goose-stepping in militaristic parades (generally speaking), but thatâ€™s also not what Nazism is actually about. The death camps came later; it started with narrowly defining who belongs and who doesnâ€™t belong. To put it another way, Nazism started by enforcing a monoculture: while not every monoculture leads to fascism, fascism always begins with enforcing conformity.

Iâ€™ve written a lot in the past about how Iâ€™m uncomfortable with the ideas of patriotism and nationalism. Both seem arbitrary: the idea of being proud of the place you happened to be born in is random. I think itâ€™s better to be proud of ideas and of values. But ultimately patriotism is fairly benign: if you want to be proud of your town, state, or country somewhere that you happened to be born in or have adopted as home, whatever. Itâ€™s not my thing, but please enjoy.

Nationalism, on the other hand, describes identification with your country of origin to the exclusion or detriment of that of people from other nations. It inherently implies harm. The question of who does and doesnâ€™t belong is actually quite complicated (I have a British accent; I have British cultural touchpoints; my hometown is Oxford; I do not hold citizenship; am I British?). In itself the question leads to a toxicity that can poison a community: in considering who belongs and who doesnâ€™t, we needfully set ourselves up for having conversations about how to exclude people.

Similarly, the question about who is and isnâ€™t a Nazi isnâ€™t actually very useful, and hangs the discourse on a very superficial question. Itâ€™s also more complicated than it appears: Hitlerâ€™s policies regarding Jewish people was in part based on American Jim Crow laws. The Nazis werenâ€™t some aberration in history: they were a part of a continuum, very much in line with what was happening elsewhere, and weâ€™ve learned that similar ideas can crop up anywhere if the conditions are right.

So Iâ€™d rather just ask: what is the society we want to create? What are the values that are important to us? I can tell you that mine are about inclusion, a broad definition of belonging, and vibrant diversity, where social structures are intentionally created that allow everyone to live a good life, where ideas and expression are open, where there is no state violence, and where anyone can innovate or create a business if they have a good enough idea.

I donâ€™t want to live in a monoculture, and will vote and make decisions on that basis. If you do, you should vote and make decisions on that basis. If the overwhelming will of the people is that monocultures are good, I will march, rally, protest, and vote in opposition to that idea. And should the monoculture decide that it needs to label the businesses created by people like me â€” or people like anyone â€” or to label the people themselves as Other, if it decides to forcibly deport them, if mobs or police go looking for them like they did for my ancestors, if it decides that it must put people into camps like the one my father spent the first few years of his life in, if it decides to burn down communities as was done to my great grandfatherâ€™s village, then I will fight, and fight hard, and I promise you there are many, many others who feel the same way. None of this is new.

In the end this comes down to who gets to be a part of the future, and fundamentally, I believe the future should be for everyone.

And, to bring this conversation back to its initial question, thatâ€™s my ideal place to live: somewhere thatâ€™s for everyone, culturally and ideologically.

Saturday, 07. September 2024

ã“ã‚“ã«ã¡ã¯ã€å¯Œå£«æ¦®ã§ã™ã€‚

ã„ã‚ˆã„ã‚ˆä»Šé€±ã¯ãƒ¯ã‚·ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒ³D.C.ã§ä»Šå¹´3å›ç›®ã®SIDI Hubã‚µãƒŸãƒƒãƒˆãŒé–‹å‚¬ã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚

ã“ã®æ¬¡ã¯10æœˆã®æ±äº¬ã€ãã—ã¦æœ€çµ‚ã‚´ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã§ã‚ã‚‹G20ä¼šåˆã«å‘ã‘ãŸãƒªã‚ªãƒ‡ã‚¸ãƒ£ãƒã‚¤ãƒ­ä¼šåˆãŒ11æœˆã«æ§ãˆã¾ã™ã€‚



ãã‚ãã‚ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³ä¼šåˆã®ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚‚èª­ã¿çµ‚ãˆã¦ãŠããŸã„ã¨ã“ã‚ã§ã™ã®ã§ã€é€²ã‚ã¦ã„ãã¾ã™ã€‚ä»Šå›ã¯ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨ã«å‘ã‘ãŸæœ€ä½é™ã®è¦æ±‚äº‹é …ã®ã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã§ã™ã€‚


ã¾ãšã€ã‚°ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ«ã§ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ã‚’ç¢ºä¿ã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«ã¯ã€ã‚‚ã¡ã‚ã‚“ä¸–ç•Œä¸­ã®å…¨ã¦ã®çµ„ç¹”ã‚„ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ãŒçµ±ä¸€ã•ã‚ŒãŸæ¨™æº–ã‚’ã‚µãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒãƒ™ã‚¹ãƒˆãªã‚ã‘ã§ã™ãŒã€ç¾å®Ÿã¯ãã†ç”˜ãã¯ãªã„ã‚ã‘ã§ã™ã€‚ãã†ãªã‚‹ã¨ã€å®Ÿè£…ãƒ‘ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã¯ä»¥ä¸‹ã®3ã¤ã«é›†ç´„ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã“ã¨ã«ãªã‚‹ã€ã¨SIDI Hubã§ã¯ä»®èª¬ã‚’ç«‹ã¦ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

ç™ºè¡Œè€…ã¨ãƒªãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚°ãƒ‘ãƒ¼ãƒ†ã‚£ãŒè¤‡æ•°ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒˆã‚³ãƒ«ã‚’å®Ÿè£…ã™ã‚‹ ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒˆã‚³ãƒ«å¤‰æ›ã‚’è¡Œã†ãƒ¬ã‚¤ãƒ¤ãƒ¼ã‚’ç”¨æ„ã™ã‚‹ ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚­ã‚·ã‚’é…ç½®ã™ã‚‹ 2ç•ªç›®ã¨3ç•ªç›®ã¯ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒˆã‚³ãƒ«å¤‰æ›ã‚’ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚­ã‚·ã§ã‚„ã‚‹ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã‚‚ã‚ã‚‹ã®ã§å®Ÿè³ªã¯åŒã˜å½¢ã§ã®å®Ÿè£…ã¨ãªã‚‹å¯èƒ½æ€§ã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šãã†ã§ã™ã€‚
ã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã§ã¯ãƒšã‚¤ãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆã¨é€é‡‘ã€æ•™è‚²ã€ãã—ã¦å›½å¢ƒã‚’è¶…ãˆãŸå•†å–å¼•ã®2ã¤ã®ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹æœ€ä½é™ã®è¦æ±‚äº‹é …ã®åˆ†æã‚’ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
ä¾‹ãˆã°ãƒšã‚¤ãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆã¨é€é‡‘ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã¯ä»¥ä¸‹ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«åˆ†æã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¹ å›½å¢ƒã‚’è¶…ãˆãŸé€é‡‘ã¨å—ã‘å–ã‚Š ä¸æ­£ã‚’é˜²æ­¢ã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«å—å–äººã®IDã®ç¢ºèª å—å–äººã®å£åº§ã®ç¢ºèª æ”¯æ‰•ã„ã‹ã‚‰ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ã®ã‹ã€å—å–è¦æ±‚ã‹ã‚‰ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ã®ã‹ åˆ¶è£ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯ KYCæƒ…å ±ã®åé›†ã€æ³•è¦åˆ¶ã¸ã®æº–æ‹  ç¨å‹™æƒ…å ± ã‚¨ã‚¯ã‚¹ãƒ­ãƒ¼ã‚„å–å¼•ä»²ä»‹è€… â†’ãŸã—ã‹ã«ã“ã‚Œã‚‰ã‚’å›½å¢ƒã‚„åˆ¶åº¦ãŒç•°ãªã‚‹å›½å®¶é–“ã§å®Ÿæ–½ã™ã‚‹ã®ã¯ã‚¢ãƒ•ãƒªã‚«ã«é™ã‚‰ãšéå¸¸ã«å›°é›£ã‚’ä¼´ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ä¾‹ãˆã°æµ·å¤–é€é‡‘ã‚’ã™ã‚‹éš›ã«å—å–äººãŒãƒ†ãƒ­ãƒªã‚¹ãƒˆã§ãªã„ã“ã¨ã‚’ã©ã†ã‚„ã£ã¦ç¢ºèªã™ã‚‹ã®ã‹ï¼Ÿã¨ã„ã†ã®ã¯éå¸¸ã«é›£ã—ã„å•é¡Œã«ãªã‚Šãã†ã§ã™ã—ã€ã‚ªãƒ³ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ³é€é‡‘ã‚’ã™ã‚‹éš›ã®ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒ•ã‚§ã‚¤ã‚¹ã®å•é¡Œã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ã‚‚ã¡ã‚ã‚“å¤ãã¯CHIPSã®ã‚ˆã†ãªã‚¯ãƒªã‚¢ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ãƒã‚¦ã‚¹ã‚„ç¾è¡Œã®SWIFTãªã©ãŒå›½éš›é€é‡‘ã§ã¯å­˜åœ¨ã™ã‚‹ã‚ã‘ã§ã™ãŒã€æ—¥å¸¸çš„ã«å›½å¢ƒã‚’è¶…ãˆã¦å•†å£²ã‚’ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å›½ã€…ã«ãŠã„ã¦ãã‚Œã‚‰ã®ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¯éå‰°ã¨ã‚‚è¨€ãˆã‚‹ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚
ä¸¡ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ‰ã«ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¯å°å…¥ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹ã®ã‹ï¼Ÿ ç®¡è½„é ˜åŸŸã«ä¾å­˜ã€ã‚ã£ãŸã¨ã—ã¦ã‚‚ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ãŒãªã„å ´åˆãŒå¤šã„ æŠ€è¡“çš„ãªå±•æœ› è¤‡æ•°ã®æ±ºæ¸ˆã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã‚„ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¯å¿…ãšã—ã‚‚ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨å¯èƒ½ã§ã¯ãªã„ ã»ã¨ã‚“ã©ã®å›½ãŒFATFã®AMLè¦ä»¶ã«æº–æ‹ ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ å¤šæ§˜ãªã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒå­˜åœ¨ã€ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ãŒãªã„ ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«è³‡ç”£ã®å–å¼•ã«ã¯ç•°ãªã‚‹è¦åˆ¶è¦ä»¶ãŒã‚ã‚Šã€ä¿è¨¼ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã‚‚ç•°ãªã‚‹ æŠ€è¡“çš„ãªèª²é¡Œ å…±é€šã®ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãŒå­˜åœ¨ã›ãšã€ç™ºè¡Œè€…ã”ã¨ã«ç•°ãªã‚‹ä¿è¨¼ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã¨ãªã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ å›½å®¶é–“ã€å›½å†…ã«ãŠã„ã¦ã‚‚ä¸€è²«æ€§ã®ãªã„â€æ¨™æº–â€ã®åˆ©ç”¨ IDã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®éµç®¡ç†ã®å•é¡Œ webã‚„mobile OSãªã©è¤‡æ•°ã®ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ ã§åˆ©ç”¨ã§ãã‚‹ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒ‡ãƒ³ã‚·ãƒ£ãƒ«ãŒå¿…è¦
ã“ã†ãªã£ã¦ãã‚‹ã¨æŠ€è¡“ã®ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ã®ã¿ãªã‚‰ãšãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã®ãƒãƒƒãƒ”ãƒ³ã‚°ãªã©ã‚‚åˆã‚ã›ã¦é€²ã‚ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã­ã€‚ã¾ãã€ã“ã®è¾ºã‚Šã¯å¼•ãç¶šãæ•´ç†ã‚’ç¶šã‘ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã®ã§æ±äº¬ä¼šåˆã®æ™‚ã«ã¯ã‚ã‚‹ç¨‹åº¦ã¾ã¨ã¾ã£ã¦ãã‚‹ã‚“ã˜ã‚ƒãªã„ã‹ãªï¼Ÿã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

22:22 • 17 days ago

â†’èˆˆå‘³æ·±ã„ã§ã™ã­ã€‚æ”¿åºœãªã©ã®æ©Ÿé–¢ã«ä¿¡é ¼ã®åŸºç‚¹ã‚’ç½®ãå¿…è¦ãŒå«ã°ã‚Œã¤ã¤ã‚‚ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã«ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£æƒ…å ±ã‚’æ ¼ç´ã—ã¦æŒã¡é‹ã¶ã€ã¨ã„ã†ã¨ã“ã‚ã«ã“ã‚Œã¾ã§ã€Œè‡ªå·±ä¸»æ¨©ã€ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã‚’å«ã‚“ã§ããŸäººãŸã¡ã«ã¨ã£ã¦ã¯çŸ›ç›¾ã‚’ç”£ã¿å§‹ã‚ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã®ã‹ã‚‚ã—ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚
è¦åˆ¶ã®èƒŒæ™¯ã‚’ç†è§£ã™ã‚‹ï¼š ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£ã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹æ”¿åºœã®å½¹å‰² ãƒ¨ãƒ¼ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒ‘ã®è¦åˆ¶ç’°å¢ƒã‹ã‚‰æ±å—ã‚¢ã‚¸ã‚¢ã‚„ã‚¢ãƒ•ãƒªã‚«ã®ãƒ€ã‚¤ãƒŠãƒŸãƒƒã‚¯ãªãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ãƒ» ãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒ‰ã‚¹ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã¾ã§ã€ç§ãŒåƒã„ã¦ããŸã©ã®åœ°åŸŸã§ã‚‚ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚½ãƒªãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã®ä¿¡é ¼ç¢ºç«‹ã« ãŠã‘ã‚‹æ”¿åºœã®ä¸­å¿ƒçš„å½¹å‰²ã¯ä¸€è²«ã—ãŸè¦å› ã§ã‚ã£ãŸã€‚ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ‰ã‚„ä¸­å›½ã®å›½å®¶ ID ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒ ã§ã‚ã‚ã†ã¨ã€ã‚¢ãƒ•ãƒªã‚«ã®å›½å®¶ãŒæ”¯æ´ã™ã‚‹ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID æ çµ„ã¿ã§ã‚ã‚ã†ã¨ã€æ”¿åºœã®é–¢ä¸ã¯å¤§é‡æ¡ç”¨ã¨ä¿¡é ¼ã®é”æˆã«ä¸å¯æ¬ ã§ã‚ã£ãŸã€‚ ã“ã‚Œã‚‰ã®çµŒé¨“ã¯ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ãŒæˆåŠŸã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«ã¯ã€ãã®å¦¥å½“æ€§ã¨ã‚»ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒª ãƒ†ã‚£ã‚’ä¿è¨¼ã™ã‚‹æ¨©å¨ã‚ã‚‹æƒ…å ±æºï¼ˆé€šå¸¸ã¯æ”¿åºœï¼‰ãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã‚ã‚‹ã¨ã„ã†é‡å¤§ãªç¾å®Ÿã‚’æµ®ãå½«ã‚Šã«ã— ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚æ”¿åºœã¯å€‹äººãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãŠã‚ˆã³å…¬å…±ã®åˆ©ç›Šã®ä¸»è¦ãªç®¡ç†è€…ã¨è¦‹ãªã•ã‚Œã‚‹ãŸã‚ã€å€‹äººã¯æ”¿åºœã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦æ”¯ æŒã•ã‚Œã‚‹ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚’ä¿¡é ¼ã™ã‚‹ã€‚æ”¿åºœã®æ‰¿èªã¾ãŸã¯èªè­˜ãŒãªã‘ã‚Œã°ã€å¤šãã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¤ãƒ‹ã‚·ã‚¢ãƒãƒ– ã¯ã€ãã®æŠ€è¡“é©æ–°ã«ã‹ã‹ã‚ã‚‰ãšã€ç‰½å¼•åŠ›ã‚’å¾—ã‚‹ã®ã«è‹¦åŠ´ã™ã‚‹ã€‚
â†’é©ç”¨é ˜åŸŸæ¬¡ç¬¬ã ã‚ã†ã¨ã¯æ€ã„ã¾ã™ãŒã€æ”¿åºœã‚’å«ã‚€æ¨©å¨ã®ã‚ã‚‹æƒ…å ±ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚¹ãŒãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£ã«é–¢ã™ã‚‹ä¿¡é ¼ã®åŸºç‚¹ã«ãªã‚Šã‚„ã™ã„ã®ã¯äº‹å®Ÿã ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ä¸€æ–¹ã§ã“ã®ã“ã¨ãŒå…ˆæ—¥ã®ID Dayã®è©±ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«å›½å®¶ã«ãƒã‚°ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆã•ã‚ŒãŸäººãŸã¡ãŒå­˜åœ¨ã™ã‚‹è¦å› ã®ä¸€ã¤ã«ã‚‚ãªã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã‚‚äº‹å®Ÿã§ã™ã€‚ã‚„ã¯ã‚Šäººé¡ã¯ã€Œä¿¡é ¼ã€ã«ã¤ã„ã¦æ·±ãè€ƒå¯Ÿã™ã¹ãæ™‚æœŸã«æ¥ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã‚“ã˜ã‚ƒãªã„ã‹ã¨ãŠã‚‚ã¾ã™ã€‚ Open Walletã®èª²é¡Œï¼š eIDAS 2.0è¦åˆ¶ã¸ã®å¯¾å¿œ åˆ†æ•£å‹ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ãƒ»ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã¨ã„ã†ãƒ“ã‚¸ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’æ²ã’ã‚‹Open Wallet Foundationã¯ã€ã“ã®æ–‡è„ˆã«ãŠã„ã¦å¤§ããªèª²é¡Œã«ç›´é¢ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚eIDAS 2.0 ä»•æ§˜è‰æ¡ˆã¯ã€æ¬§å·é€£åˆå†…ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã¯å›½å®¶ç™ºè¡Œã¾ãŸã¯å›½å®¶æ‰¿èªã§ãªã‘ã‚Œã°ãªã‚‰ãšã€ã“ ã‚Œã‚‰ã® ID ã«å¯¾ã™ã‚‹ä¿¡é ¼ã¯æœ¬è³ªçš„ã«æ”¿åºœã®æ¨©å¨ã¨çµã³ã¤ã„ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã¨æ˜è¨€ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚ã“ã®æ çµ„ã¿ã¯ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«å¯¾ã™ã‚‹å›½ã®ç®¡ç†ã‚’å¼·åŒ–ã™ã‚‹åºƒç¯„ãªå‚¾å‘ã‚’åæ˜ ã— ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚ Open Walletã«ã¨ã£ã¦ã€ã“ã®è¦åˆ¶ç’°å¢ƒã¯é‡å¤§ãªã‚¸ãƒ¬ãƒ³ãƒã‚’ã‚‚ãŸã‚‰ã™ã€‚ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã®åŸå‰‡ã¨åŒ…æ‹¬çš„ãªé–‹ç™ºã¸ã®ã‚³ãƒŸãƒƒãƒˆãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆã¯è³è³›ã«å€¤ã™ã‚‹ãŒã€ãã®ç¾åœ¨ã®ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒã¯ã€æ”¿åºœä¸»å°ã®æ çµ„ã¿ã¸ã®æº–æ‹ ãŒä¸å¯æ¬ ãªEUã®ã‚ˆã†ãªä¸»è¦å¸‚å ´ã®è¦åˆ¶ã®ç¾å®Ÿã¨ä¸€è‡´ã—ãªã„å¯èƒ½æ€§ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã€‚å›½å®¶ãŒæ”¯æ´ã™ã‚‹ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ãƒ»ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ»ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¸ã®ç§»è¡Œã¯ã€ç‰¹ã«æ”¿åºœè¦åˆ¶ã®éµå®ˆãŒç¾©å‹™ä»˜ã‘ã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹æ³•åŸŸã§ã¯ã€ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ¬ã‚¹ãƒ»ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã®ä½™åœ°ãŒé™ã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹å¯èƒ½æ€§ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã‚’ç¤ºå”†ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚
â†’ã¾ã•ã«å…ˆã«æ›¸ã„ãŸé€šã‚Šã§ã™ã€‚åˆ†æ•£å‹ã§ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³æ€§ã‚’æ²ã’ã‚‹ä¸€æ–¹ã§æ”¿åºœã«ä¿¡é ¼ã®åŸºç‚¹ã‚’ç½®ã‹ã–ã‚‹ã‚’å¾—ãªã„ã€ã¨ã„ã†ã®ã¯çŸ›ç›¾ã™ã‚‹å¯èƒ½æ€§ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚

â†’ãªã‹ãªã‹åˆºæ¿€çš„ãªæè¨€ã§ã™ã­ã€‚è¡Œãéããªæ°—ã¯ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ã‚ãã¾ã§å®Ÿè£…ã¨ã—ã¦ã®Open Walletã¨æ”¿åºœã«ä¿¡é ¼ã®åŸºç‚¹ã‚’ç½®ãã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒ‡ãƒ³ã‚·ãƒ£ãƒ«ã¯ä¸¡ç«‹ã§ãã‚‹ã‚“ã˜ã‚ƒãªã„ã®ã‹ï¼Ÿã¨ã‚‚æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
B. æ”¿åºœé–“å”åŠ›ã¸ã®è»¸è¶³ Open Walletã¯ã€ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ¬ã‚¹ãƒ»ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ãƒ»ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ»ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã‚’ç¶™ç¶šã™ã‚‹ä»£ã‚ã‚Šã«ã€æ”¿åºœã¨ã®å”åŠ›ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦æ—¢å­˜ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã‚’å¼·åŒ–ã™ã‚‹æ–¹å‘ã«è»¸è¶³ã‚’ç§»ã™ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã‚‹ã€‚ã“ã‚Œã«ã¯ã€æ”¿åºœä¸»å°ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¤ãƒ‹ã‚·ã‚¢ãƒãƒ–ã‚’è£œå®Œã—ã‚µãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã®ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã€ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã€ã¾ãŸã¯æ¨™æº–ã‚’é–‹ç™ºã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒå«ã¾ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚æ”¿åºœã®è¦æ±‚ã¨é€£æºã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã€ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã¯ã‚¤ãƒãƒ™ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’ä¿ƒé€²ã—ãªãŒã‚‰ã€ã‚°ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ«ãªãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDã‚¨ã‚³ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«ãŠã„ã¦é–¢é€£æ€§ã‚’ä¿ã¤ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚
â†’ã“ã‚Œã¯ä¸€éƒ¨ã§ã‚„ã£ã¦ã‚‹ã‚“ã˜ã‚ƒãªã„ã®ï¼Ÿã¨ã‚‚æ€ã„ã¾ã™ãŒã€ã¡ã‚ƒã‚“ã¨æ”¿åºœã®æ–¹å‘æ€§ã¨ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒªã‚¯ãƒˆãŒãªã„å½¢ã‚’ç›®æŒ‡ã—ã¦ã„ãã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€ã£ã¦ã¨ã“ã‚ã§ã™ã­ã€‚
C. ã‚¤ãƒãƒ™ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã¨ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚¤ã‚¢ãƒ³ã‚¹ã®ãƒãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚’ã¨ã‚‹ãƒã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒªãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã®æå”± OpenWallet ã¯ã€ãã®åŒ…æ‹¬çš„ãªãƒãƒ«ãƒã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ›ãƒ«ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒã¨è¦åˆ¶éµå®ˆã®å¿…è¦æ€§ã®ãƒãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚’ã¨ã‚‹ãƒã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒªãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã‚’æ¨¡ç´¢ã™ã¹ãã§ã™ã€‚eIDAS 2.0ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªè¦åˆ¶ã®éµå®ˆã«ç„¦ç‚¹ã‚’å½“ã¦ãŸå°‚é–€ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚­ãƒ³ã‚°ã‚°ãƒ«ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚’çµæˆã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã¯ã€ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³æ€§ã¸ã®ã‚³ãƒŸãƒƒãƒˆãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚’ç¶­æŒã—ãªãŒã‚‰ã€OpenWalletã®ãƒ“ã‚¸ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’æ³•çš„è¦ä»¶ã¨æ•´åˆã•ã›ã‚‹ã®ã«å½¹ç«‹ã¤ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚EUã®è¦åˆ¶å½“å±€ã‚„ä»–ã®æ¨™æº–åŒ–å›£ä½“ã¨ç›´æ¥é–¢ã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã€è²´é‡ãªæ´å¯Ÿã‚„æŒ‡é‡ãŒå¾—ã‚‰ã‚Œã‚‹ã ã‚ã†ã€‚
â†’ã¾ãã€ãã†ãªã‚Šã¾ã™ã‚ˆã­ã€‚æˆ¦ã£ã¦ã‚‚ä»•æ–¹ãªã„è©±ãªã®ã§ã€å‰é …ã«ã‚‚ã‚ã‚‹é€šã‚Šæ­©èª¿ã‚’åˆã‚ã›ã‚‹ã£ã¦ã„ã†ã“ã¨ãŒå¿…è¦ã«ãªã‚Šãã†ã§ã™ã€‚ä»Šæ›´ãªãŒã‚‰ã§ã™ãŒãƒãƒ«ãƒã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ›ãƒ«ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã¨ã„ã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ä¸­ã®é‡è¦ãªä¸€éƒ¨ã¨ã—ã¦æ”¿åºœã‚‚å…¥ã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã§ã™ã€‚
D. ä¸»è¦ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ›ãƒ«ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã¨ã®ç¶™ç¶šçš„ãªå¯¾è©±ã®ä¿ƒé€² é–¢é€£æ€§ã‚’ç¶­æŒã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«ã€Open Walletã¯è¦åˆ¶å½“å±€ã€æ”¿ç­–ç«‹æ¡ˆè€…ã€ãŠã‚ˆã³ãã®ä»–ã®ä¸»è¦ãªåˆ©å®³é–¢ä¿‚ è€…ã¨ç¶™ç¶šçš„ã«å¯¾è©±ã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚å”è­°ã«å‚åŠ ã—ã€ãƒ•ã‚£ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’æä¾›ã—ã€ãƒ™ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ã‚¹ã‚’å…±æœ‰ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã€Open Walletã¯ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID æ¨™æº–ã®é€²åŒ–ã«è²¢çŒ®ã™ã‚‹è²´é‡ãªå­˜åœ¨ã¨ã—ã¦ä½ç½®ä»˜ã‘ã‚‰ã‚Œã€æ–°ãŸãªè¦åˆ¶ã®å‹•å‘ã« å¿œã˜ã¦æˆ¦ç•¥ã‚’é©å¿œã•ã›ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚
â†’å‰é …ã¾ã§ã¨ä¸€ç·’ã§ã™ã­ã€‚ã‚ã‚‹ç¨‹åº¦æ­©èª¿ã¯åˆã‚ã›ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ãŒã€ã‚‚ã£ã¨æ˜ç¢ºã«ã‚„ã£ã¦ã„ãã¹ããªã®ã‹ã‚‚ã—ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£æˆ¦ç•¥ã®å†ç·¨ ã‚¨ãƒ³ãƒ‰ãƒ»ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ»ã‚¨ãƒ³ãƒ‰ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ãƒ»ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£ã®å°‚é–€å®¶ã¨ã—ã¦ã€ç§ã¯Open Wallet Foundationã¨ãã®ä»–ã®é–¢ä¿‚è€…ã«å¯¾ã—ã€é€²åŒ–ã™ã‚‹è¦åˆ¶ã®çŠ¶æ³ã«ç…§ã‚‰ã—ã¦ç¾åœ¨ã®ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒã‚’æ‰¹åˆ¤çš„ã«è©•ä¾¡ã™ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†å¼·ãæ±‚ã‚ã¾ã™ã€‚ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDã®ä¿¡é ¼ã®ç¤ã¨ã—ã¦ã®æ”¿åºœã®å½¹å‰²ã‚’èªè­˜ã—ã€ã‚ªãƒ¼ãƒ—ãƒ³ã‚½ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã®ã‚¤ãƒãƒ™ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’å›½å®¶ä¸»å°ã®ãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã¨é€£æºã•ã›ã‚‹æ–°ãŸãªæ–¹æ³•ã‚’æ¨¡ç´¢ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒä¸å¯æ¬ ã§ã™ã€‚ ç§ã¯ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚³ãƒŸãƒ¥ãƒ‹ãƒ†ã‚£ã«å¯¾ã—ã€æ”¿åºœãŠã‚ˆã³è¦åˆ¶å½“å±€ã¨ã®å”åŠ›é–¢ä¿‚ã‚’å¼·åŒ–ã—ã€é©æ–°çš„ã§ã€æº–æ‹  æ€§ãŒé«˜ãã€å®‰å…¨ã§ã€åºƒãå—ã‘å…¥ã‚Œã‚‰ã‚Œã‚‹ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚½ãƒªãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’é–‹ç™ºã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã®å…±é€šåŸºç›¤ã‚’è¦‹å‡ºã™ã‚ˆã†å‘¼ã³ã‹ã‘ã‚‹ã€‚
â†’è‰¯ã„æŠ•ã’è¾¼ã¿ã§ã™ã­ã€‚ã“ã†ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã‚’é–¢ä¿‚è€…ãŒã¡ã‚ƒã‚“ã¨æ„è­˜ã‚’ã™ã‚‹è‰¯ã„ãã£ã‹ã‘ã«ãªã‚‹ã¨è‰¯ã„ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã‚Œã¯ã‚‚ã¡ã‚ã‚“æ—¥æœ¬ã«ãŠã„ã¦ã‚‚ã€ã§ã™ã€‚
ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ãƒ»ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£ã®ç¾å®Ÿçš„ãªé“ç­‹ ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã®å°†æ¥ã¯ã€é©æ–°ã€ä¿¡é ¼ã€ãŠã‚ˆã³è¦åˆ¶ã®é–“ã®å¾®å¦™ãªãƒãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¹ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦å½¢æˆã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã€‚eIDAS 2.0 ãƒ‰ãƒ©ãƒ•ãƒˆä»•æ§˜ãŒç¤ºã™ã‚ˆã†ã«ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã®ä¿¡é ¼ã¯ä¾ç„¶ã¨ã—ã¦æ”¿åºœã®æ¨©é™ã¨ç›£è¦–ã¨å¯†æ¥ã«é–¢ä¿‚ ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚Open Walletã®ã‚ˆã†ãªã‚¤ãƒ‹ã‚·ã‚¢ãƒãƒ–ã«ã¨ã£ã¦ã€ã“ã®ç¾å®Ÿã¯æˆ¦ç•¥çš„ãªå†è©•ä¾¡ã‚’å¿…è¦ã¨ã™ã‚‹ã€‚ ç¾åœ¨ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’çµ‚äº†ã—ã€è¦åˆ¶ã®æ çµ„ã¿ã«æ²¿ã£ãŸãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã«è»¸è¶³ã‚’ç§»ã™ã“ã¨ã§ã€Open Walletã¯ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¨ã‚³ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«æœ‰æ„ç¾©ãªè²¢çŒ®ã‚’ç¶šã‘ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã‚‹ã€‚ã“ã®ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒã«ã‚ˆã‚Šã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚½ãƒªãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã¯ã€è¦åˆ¶ã®æœŸå¾…ã‚’å°Šé‡ã—ãªãŒã‚‰ã‚‚ã€å¤šæ§˜ãªåœ°åŸŸã® ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ã®ãƒ‹ãƒ¼ã‚ºã‚’æº€ãŸã—ã€ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ‘ã‚¯ãƒˆãŒã‚ã‚Šã€ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚¤ã‚¢ãƒ³ã‚¹ãŒã‚ã‚Šã€ä¸–ç•Œçš„ã«é©åˆ‡ãªã‚‚ã®ã¨ãªã‚‹ã€‚
â†’Open Wallet FoundationãŒã©ã†ã—ã¦ã„ãã¹ãã‹ã€ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã¯å¿…è¦ä»¥ä¸Šã«ã“ã“ã§ã¯è§¦ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ãŒã€æŠ€è¡“ã ã‘ã§ã¯ãƒ€ãƒ¡ã§ã€è¦åˆ¶ã€ãã—ã¦ãã‚‚ãã‚‚ã€Œä¿¡é ¼ã€ã¯ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«ã—ã¦é†¸æˆã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã®ã‹ï¼Ÿã‚’è€ƒãˆã¦ã„ã‘ã‚‹ã¨è‰¯ã„ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ï¼ˆã“ã‚Œã¯ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã«é™ã‚‰ãšå…¨ã¦ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«ã¤ã„ã¦è¨€ãˆã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã™ãŒï¼‰

ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã§èˆˆå‘³æ·±ãèª­ã¾ã›ã¦ã„ãŸã ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚
02:04 • 18 days ago

Friday, 06. September 2024

Michael Ruminer

Having AI Tools Generate Code For AI Tools

I recently posted on my experience with using a few Python examples of retrieval augmented generation (RAG) with an LLM (OpenAI API). They were underwhelming, though they did provide a lot of insight for me. This post is about my next experiment: letâ€™s get AI tools to generate examples for me. The results were mixed but not for reasons you might think. Hereâ€™s what I found using ChatGPT, Microsoft

I recently posted on my experience with using a few Python examples of retrieval augmented generation (RAG) with an LLM (OpenAI API). They were underwhelming, though they did provide a lot of insight for me. This post is about my next experiment: letâ€™s get AI tools to generate examples for me. The results were mixed but not for reasons you might think. Hereâ€™s what I found using ChatGPT, Microsoft Copilot and Cursor.

Note: you can find the generated code in my LLM_Generated_RAG Github repo. I will likely add to this repo as I try new prompts, LLMs, and approaches.

ChatGPT 4o

Letâ€™s start with the most well-known, ChatGPT. I used a simple prompt to see what it would do. I didnâ€™t provide prompts for different parts of the code. It should not be very extensive code so I didnâ€™t feel the need to divide it into separate prompts. If you want to see my very elementary prompt pull up the ChatGPT related file in the repo.

The first thing I noticed is that it was using PyPDF2 which was deprecated in Decemeber of 2022. Not surprising as, almost certainly, a lot of what the model was trained on used PyPDF2. It actually created well-structured code with functions for the different discrete operations. What I realized later, due to the output of the Cursor tool, is that it created a more granular set of code than it had to. This is exactly what I was looking for but didnâ€™t specify in the prompt. What do I mean? It did the following:

read the PDF and extracted the text split the document into chunks created embeddings for the chunks using the OpenAI text-embedding-ada-002 created an embedding for the query searched the chunks using faiss generated a response using the query and the chunk(s) as context

This is what I wanted. Turns out there was a very different way to interpret the prompt.

The downside. The code didnâ€™t run out the box. Also, I believe it only used one chunk for the context to send along with the query. I have to investigate the code more closely to be sure on that single chunk thing. The embedding search chunk function I need to investigate more to understand it. I didnâ€™t try to make the code run for now as that was not part of the experiment. I expect I will try to modify it soon to function. Iâ€™ll report back the results.

This granular set of actions was very different than what I got from Cursor.

Cursor

The Cursor prompt was not exactly the same as what I used for ChatGPT, which was bad of me to do. I got a little lazier, but the crux was the same. You can see that prompt here.

The results were very different. It did not provide the granular steps that ChatGPT did. It met the requirement more succinctly.

extract the text from the PDF, also using PyPDF2 pass the entire text to ChatGPT as context along with the prompt

When I first posted this I said it rain out of the gate, but that was wrong. It suffered from the same issue all three code generations did. It tried to use an old call of openai chat completion. With that fixed I believe it would, hypothetically, return the expected results. It would work similarly to how one does it in the ChatGPT interface. Not what I wanted, but I hadnâ€™t specified to break it down so that I was creating embeddings etc. Fair game.

The downside, the context was too large (43,000+ tokens) for the tokens per minute limit of my OpenAPI account level and gpt-4o model (see attached note for an explanation). So I didnâ€™t get to see the output, but have no doubt it would have produced similar results as if I had done it through the ChatGPT user interface.

Microsoft Copilot

What can I say? I donâ€™t know what I would have gotten here because Copilot blocked the output. This is apparently because â€œGitHub Copilot checks code completion suggestions with their surrounding code of about 150 characters against public code on GitHub. If there is a match, or a near match, the suggestion is not shown to you.â€

There is a flag you can set in your Github settings to turn this on or off. I checked and my flag and it is set to â€œAllowedâ€ but you see the results.

Iâ€™ll continue to try to troubleshoot this issue and see if I can get something out of Copilot and update this post if I do.

In recap

In recap. One provided the detail I wanted even though I hadnâ€™t specified it, a happy coincidence, but it did not run out of the gate. The second took a very different approach and would have provided the desired results in LLM response if my OpenAPI account level had supported a large enough tokens per minute for 43,000+ tokens in the context. But it wasnâ€™t the code I was hoping for. Copliot just didnâ€™t work for me for reasons I donâ€™t yet understand. More experimentation to come.

20:07 • 18 days ago

Justin Richer

Making Bubbles: Re-connecting

If a set of accounts live in isolation forever, what happens to those accounts only matters within that isolated system. But when we make a bubble in our federated network, we arenâ€™t just making a stand-alone system that can go live in a fully disconnected state. Over time, we expect things to re-connect, and when that happens, data needs to be harmonized across the boundaries. So many bubbles, so

If a set of accounts live in isolation forever, what happens to those accounts only matters within that isolated system. But when we make a bubble in our federated network, we arenâ€™t just making a stand-alone system that can go live in a fully disconnected state. Over time, we expect things to re-connect, and when that happens, data needs to be harmonized across the boundaries.

So many bubbles, so many connections Data Synchronization

When multiple independent systems live together in the world and share data, inevitably that data is going to get out of sync. In a purely heirarchical system, weâ€™re mostly concerned with building a consensus around the correct state of the shared data. We see this approach in distributed ledger systems, where nodes eventually come to a common view of what the shared state of the world ought to be.

But we donâ€™t have that in a bubble-based architecture, because we donâ€™t expect everyone to have the same view. Instead, we expect many different independent views to contribute to each other in a distributed fashion. This effectively means that for each bubble, it can send updates in and out to other systems. In most cases, there is a directionality to the data flow: one side is going to be treated as more authoritative than the other for a given context. What a bubble does when itâ€™s on either end of that gap changes how we view the synchronization.

Account Updates From Above

When changes are pushed to us from an authoritative source, the simplest thing is to overwrite everything. After all, if itâ€™s authoritative, why wouldnâ€™t we just take that statement as truth? But the reality is that weâ€™ve likely augmented our record of that user with additional details, overrides, and other localized changes that we donâ€™t want to lose.

Local data (blue) shadows updates from the source (orange), in some cases

In these cases, we can shadow the data. In other words, we keep a copy of the sourceâ€™s data separate from our own local view. When we get an update from that source, we can update our copy of the sourceâ€™s data with wild abandon. We can then decide, by local policy, whether we want to adjust our overrides based on the update. Importantly, this decision is separate from accepting and processing the updated data from the source. This setup allows us to keep local information in the bubble at the same time that we sync from elsewhere.

Account Updates From Below

An authoritative bubble is sometimes going to want to pull updated information from the bubbles that live downstream. These are systems that weâ€™ve sent accounts out to, and those systems might have something to tell us about our users. Maybe thereâ€™s an additional accreditation thatâ€™s been earned, or something to represent additional access details outside of our bubble, or even just an update to one of the core fields we sent down.

In any case, the downstream bubble is sending us additional data about a user, and we now have the chance to do something about it. If nothing else, we can store it and note it. If we want to, we can update the userâ€™s record that we hold locally, and even go so far as to propagate that downward again to other bubbles.

Changing Trust

Itâ€™s not just user data that we can pass around, though thatâ€™s the most common piece weâ€™d expect to see. The bubbles can also pass about other bubbles to each other, and incorporate what they learn into their own systems.

For many situations that fit the bubble architecture patterns, we expect to meet new peers in the field and make new decisions based on local context and requirements. These newly-discovered bubbles can then be propagated through the network, along with potentially interesting information about what the presenting bubble trusts it for.

Audit Logs

Now that we can identify users and the systems they come from, we can start to do one of the most interesting and perhaps complex jobs of a reconnected bubble: audit logs. When a bubble gets provisioned, that provisioning authority is likely to want to know what happens in that bubble during the disconnected spells. The bubble can package up the relevant audit log history and pass it along to the authorities that need it.

But auditing can go further than that: for any user that enters our bubble from somewhere else, we probably want to report back to the system that sent them to us. Since we know where we originally learned of them, and we know how to identify that system as a whole, we can filter and target the information weâ€™re sending over. And we can do this while processing the updates theyâ€™re sending us about the account.

Conclusion

The bubble pattern sits between the always-connected and always-separate models, but the moment of reconnection gives us a profound opportunity to process user and trust data in ways that we may have never considered.

16:29 • 19 days ago

Thursday, 05. September 2024

IdM Laboratory

â€»ã¤ã¾ã‚Šã€ã€ŒIssuer-Holder-Verifierã€ã¨ã„ã†3ãƒ‘ãƒ¼ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ï¼ˆIHVãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ï¼‰ã®è©±ã‚’ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã®ã«ã€é€”ä¸­ã‹ã‚‰ã€ŒIssuer-Wallet-Verifierã€ã¨ã„ã†ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«æ„ŸãŒåˆã‚ãªã„è©±ã«ã™ã‚Šæ›¿ã‚ã£ã¦ã—ã¾ã†ã¨ã„ã†è©±ã§ã™ã€‚
ã“ã®æ‚©ã¿ã«ã‚‚é–¢é€£ã—ã¾ã™ãŒã€æˆ‘ã‚‰ãŒã‚¢ãƒ³ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¼ï¼ˆAndrew Hindleï¼‰ãŒè‰¯ã„ã‚³ãƒ©ãƒ ã‚’æ›¸ã„ã¦ã„ãŸã®ã§ç´¹ä»‹ã—ã¦ãŠãã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚
Identity Wallets as Infrastructure - Andrew Hindle https://www.hindleconsulting.com/posts/wallets_as_infrastructure/

ç§ã‚‚ãŸã¾ã«ã€Œã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®ä¹±ç«‹ã£ã¦ä»Šå¾Œã©ã†ãªã‚‹ã®ï¼Ÿã€ã£ã¦èã‹ã‚Œã¾ã™ãŒã€æœ€è¿‘ã¯ã€Œã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã¨ã—ã¦ç‹¬ç«‹ã—ãŸã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã¨ã—ã¦æ‰ãˆã‚‹æ™‚ä»£ã¯çµ‚ã‚ã‚‹ã‚“ã˜ã‚ƒãªã„ï¼Ÿã‚‚ã£ã¨ä¸Šä½ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã®ä¸­ã«è‡ªç„¶ã¨å­˜åœ¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹çŠ¶æ…‹ã«ãªã£ã¦è¦‹ãˆãªããªã‚‹ã£ã¦ã„ã†ã®ãŒãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ã«ã¨ã£ã¦è‡ªç„¶ãªã®ã§ã¯ï¼Ÿã€ãªã‚“ã¦è¨€ã£ã¦ã„ãŸã‚Šã‚‚ã—ã¾ã™ãŒã€ã€Œä¹±ç«‹ã‹ã‚‰é›†ç´„ã¸ã€ã¨ã„ã†Andrewã®æ„è¦‹ã¨ã€Œä¹±ç«‹ã‹ã‚‰ä¸å¯è¦–ã¸ã€ã¨ã„ã†ç§ã®æ„è¦‹ã¯ç•°ãªã‚‹ç‚¹ã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ãŒã€å…±é€šUXã¨ã—ã¦è‡ªç„¶ã«æº¶ã‘è¾¼ã‚“ã§ã„ãã“ã¨ã«ãªã‚‰ãªã„ã¨æ™®åŠã—ãªã„ã€ã¨ã„ã†ç‚¹ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã¯ä¸€è‡´ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒãƒ£ã¨ã—ã¦ã®ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆ ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®ä¸–ç•Œã¯ã€ã“ã‚Œã‹ã‚‰ã•ã‚‰ã«é¢ç™½ããªã‚Šãã†ã§ã™ã€‚æ¬§å·é€£åˆã¯EIDAS v2ã‚’å±•é–‹ã—ã€ãƒ¢ãƒã‚¤ãƒ«é‹è»¢å…è¨±è¨¼ã®æ¡ç”¨ã¯ç±³å›½å…¨åœŸã§åŠ é€Ÿã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ (æœ€è¿‘ã®ä¾‹ã¨ã—ã¦ã¯ã€ãƒ‹ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ¨ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã¨ã‚«ãƒªãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ«ãƒ‹ã‚¢)ã€‚ãã—ã¦ã€ã“ã‚Œã‚‰ã™ã¹ã¦ã‚’ã‚µãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹é‡è¦ãªæ¨™æº– (ã¨ã‚Šã‚ã‘ã€ISO 18013-5ã‚„æ¤œè¨¼å¯èƒ½ãªè³‡æ ¼æƒ…å ±ãªã©) ã¯ã¾ã™ã¾ã™ç¢ºç«‹ã•ã‚Œã¤ã¤ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ä»Šå¾Œ 3 ï½ 5 å¹´ä»¥å†…ã«ã€ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒãƒƒãƒˆ ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ã®å¤§åŠãŒå°‘ãªãã¨ã‚‚ä¸€éƒ¨ã®è³‡æ ¼æƒ…å ±ã‚’ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆ (ä»¥ä¸‹ã€å˜ã«ã€Œã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã€) ã«ä¿å­˜ã™ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ã«ãªã‚‹ã“ã¨ã¯ã»ã¼é–“é•ã„ãªã„ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚

ãã‚Œã¯ãã‚Œã§å•é¡Œã‚ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚åŸºæœ¬çš„ãªæ©Ÿèƒ½ã¯ã»ã¼åŒã˜ã§ã™ (ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ã®ä½œæˆã€ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ã®å®Œäº†ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯)ã€‚ãŸã ã—ã€ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦æä¾›ã•ã‚Œã‚‹æ©Ÿèƒ½ã¯ç•°ãªã‚Šã€ãã‚ŒãŒè‡ªåˆ†ã«ã¨ã£ã¦å½¹ç«‹ã¤ã‹ã©ã†ã‹ã€ã¾ãŸã€ãŠé‡‘ã‚’æ‰•ã„ãŸã„ã¨æ€ã†ã‹ã©ã†ã‹ã¯ã‚ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ã®ã‚¿ã‚°ä»˜ã‘ãªã©ã®ä¸€éƒ¨ã®æ©Ÿèƒ½ã¯ã€1 ç¤¾ã¾ãŸã¯ 2 ç¤¾ã®ãƒ™ãƒ³ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã® USP ã¨ã—ã¦å§‹ã¾ã‚Šã¾ã—ãŸãŒã€éœ€è¦ãŒé«˜ã¾ã‚Šã€ä»Šã§ã¯ã™ã¹ã¦ã®ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ç®¡ç†ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®å¿…é ˆæ©Ÿèƒ½ã¨ãªã£ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒä»–ã®ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã¨ç•°ãªã‚‹ç†ç”± ã§ã¯ã€ãªãœã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒé•ã†å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã®ã‹â€‹â€‹ã€ã¨ç–‘å•ã«æ€ã†ã‹ã‚‚ã—ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ãŠãã‚‰ãã€ç‰©ç†çš„ãªè²¡å¸ƒã¨åŒã˜ã‚ˆã†ã«ã€èª°ã‚‚ãŒæ¬²ã—ãŒã‚‹ã‚ã‘ã§ã¯ãªã„æ©Ÿèƒ½ã‚’ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã«æ±‚ã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã«ãªã‚‹ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚ä¾‹: ç§ã¯ä»•äº‹ã§å¹´ã«æ•°å›ç±³å›½ã«è¡Œãã¾ã™ã€‚ç±³å›½ã¯è‹±å›½ã‚ˆã‚Šã‚‚ã¯ã‚‹ã‹ã«ç¾é‡‘ä¸­å¿ƒã®çµŒæ¸ˆã§ã™ã€‚è‹±å›½ã§ã¯ã€ä»Šã§ã¯ç¾é‡‘ã‚’æŒã¡æ­©ãã“ã¨ã¯ã»ã¨ã‚“ã©ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ (è‡ªè»¢è»Šã«ä¹—ã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã¨ãã¯åˆ¥ã§ã™ãŒã€ãã®ã¨ãã¯ç·Šæ€¥æ™‚ç”¨ã« 20 ãƒãƒ³ãƒ‰ç´™å¹£ã‚’æŒã£ã¦ã„ã¾ã™)ã€‚ç±³å›½ã§ã¯æŒã¡æ­©ãã¾ã™ã€‚ç±³ãƒ‰ãƒ«ç´™å¹£ã¯è‹±ãƒãƒ³ãƒ‰ç´™å¹£ã‚ˆã‚Šã‚‚é•·ã„ã®ã§å›°ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ãã®ãŸã‚ã€ç§ã®è²¡å¸ƒã«ã¯ã€è‹±å›½ã§è²©å£²ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹å¤šãã®è²¡å¸ƒã¨ã¯ç•°ãªã‚‹å¯¸æ³•ãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã™ã€‚è¨€ã„æ›ãˆã‚Œã°ã€ç‰©ç†çš„ãªè²¡å¸ƒã«ã¯ç±³ãƒ‰ãƒ«ã¨ GDP ã®ä¸¡æ–¹ã‚’ãƒã‚¤ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ–ã§ã‚µãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã®ã§ã™ã€‚
ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®é™ç•Œ ã§ã¯ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã¨ã®é•ã„ã¯ä½•ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã‹?
ç°¡å˜ã§ã™ã€‚ã‚‚ã—ç‰©ç†çš„ãªè²¡å¸ƒãŒã€ä½¿ç”¨ã—ãŸã„é€šè²¨ã‚’ãƒã‚¤ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ–ã«ã‚µãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã—ã¦ã„ãªã„å ´åˆã¯ã€å›é¿ç­–ã‚’ç°¡å˜ã«å®Ÿè£…ã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚ç´™å¹£ã‚’åˆ¥ã®æ–¹æ³•ã§æŠ˜ã‚ŠãŸãŸã‚“ã§ã€åã¾ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ã«ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚ã‚‚ã¡ã‚ã‚“å®Œç’§ã§ã¯ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ãŒã€ã†ã¾ãã„ãã¾ã™ã€‚
ã—ã‹ã—ã€ã“ã‚Œã¯ç§ã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã«ã¯å½“ã¦ã¯ã¾ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ãŸã¨ãˆã°ã€ã‚ã‚‹å›½å®¶ãŒã€è‡ªå›½ã®èªè¨¼æƒ…å ±ã«æœ‰åŠ¹ãªã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã¯ç‰¹åˆ¥ãªå›½å®¶ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®ã¿ã§ã‚ã‚‹ã¨æ±ºå®šã—ã€ãã®ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒä»–ã®ã™ã¹ã¦ã®äººãŒé ¼ã‚Šã«ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹æ¤œè¨¼å¯èƒ½ãªèªè¨¼æƒ…å ±ã®ä¸€éƒ¨ã®æ©Ÿèƒ½ã‚’ã‚µãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã—ã¦ã„ãªã„å ´åˆ (ã¾ãŸã¯ã€æ›´æ–°ãŒååˆ†ã«é€Ÿããªã„å ´åˆãªã©)ã€ç§ã¯å›°ã£ã¦ã—ã¾ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ç§ã®å”¯ä¸€ã®é¸æŠè‚¢ã¯ 2 ã¤ã®åˆ¥ã€…ã®ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã‚’å®Ÿè¡Œã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã™ãŒã€ãã®çŠ¶æ³ã¯æ€¥é€Ÿã«æ‚ªåŒ–ã™ã‚‹å¯èƒ½æ€§ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚
ã€Œã§ã‚‚ã€ã“ã‚Œã¯å…ˆé€²å›½ã®å›½éš›çš„ãªã‚¸ã‚§ãƒƒãƒˆã‚»ãƒƒã‚¿ãƒ¼ãŒæŠ±ãˆã‚‹å•é¡Œã®ã‚ˆã†ã«æ€ãˆã‚‹ã€ã¨ã‚ãªãŸã¯è¨€ã†ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚ç¢ºã‹ã«ã€ä»–ã®æ©Ÿé–¢ãŒåŒæ§˜ã®é“ã‚’æ­©ã¿å§‹ã‚ãŸã¨æƒ³åƒã—ã¦ã¿ã¦ãã ã•ã„ã€‚ã‚¹ãƒ¼ãƒ‘ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã‚±ãƒƒãƒˆã®ãƒã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒˆåˆ¶åº¦ã«å‚åŠ ã™ã‚‹ã®ã§ã™ã‹ï¼Ÿ ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã™ï¼ éŠ€è¡Œå£åº§ã‚’é–‹è¨­ã™ã‚‹ã®ã§ã™ã‹ï¼Ÿ ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã™ï¼ å­¦æ­´ã€å°‚é–€è³‡æ ¼ã€ã¾ãŸã¯ç¦åˆ©åšç”Ÿã®è³‡æ ¼ãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã™ã‹ï¼Ÿ ã¯ã„ã€ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒã•ã‚‰ã«å¿…è¦ã«ãªã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ç‰¹å®šã®è³‡æ ¼æƒ…å ±ãŒã©ã®ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã«å…¥ã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã‹æ€ã„å‡ºã›ãªããªã‚‹ã®ã‚‚æ™‚é–“ã®å•é¡Œã§ã™ã€‚ã¾ãŸã€ãƒ‡ãƒã‚¤ã‚¹ã‚’ç´›å¤±ã—ãŸå ´åˆï¼ˆç´›å¤±ã—ãŸå ´åˆï¼‰ã€ã¾ãŸã¯ã‚¢ãƒƒãƒ—ã‚°ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ‰æ™‚ã«ä½¿ã„æ¨ã¦ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®ä¸€éƒ¨ã‚’è»¢é€ã—å¿˜ã‚ŒãŸå ´åˆã®è³‡æ ¼æƒ…å ±å›å¾©ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ã‚¹ã¯ã€è€ƒãˆãŸãã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®æ€¥å¢—ã¯æ¡ç”¨ã‚’å¦¨ã’ã‚‹ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚
ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã¨ã—ã¦ã®ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã®åŠ› ä¼æ¥­ã‚‚ã‚½ãƒ•ãƒˆã‚¦ã‚§ã‚¢ãƒ™ãƒ³ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã‚‚ã€ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã‚’æ©Ÿèƒ½ã¨ã—ã¦è€ƒãˆã‚‹ã®ã‚’ã‚„ã‚ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã¯å®Ÿéš›ã«ã¯ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒãƒ£ ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒãƒ³ãƒˆã§ã™ã€‚ã“ã®æ–‡è„ˆã§ã€Œã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒãƒ£ã€ã¨ã¯ã©ã†ã„ã†æ„å‘³ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã‹ã€‚é‰„é“ã‚„é›»åŠ›ç¶²ã‚’è€ƒãˆã¦ã¿ã¦ãã ã•ã„ã€‚å°‘ãªãã¨ã‚‚ã€ãã‚Œã‚‰ãŒä½•ã‚’è¡Œã†ã‹ã€ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«æ©Ÿèƒ½ã™ã‚‹ã‹ã¨ã„ã†åŸºæœ¬çš„ãªç‚¹ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã¯ã€èª°ã‚‚ãŒåŒæ„ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ãã‚Œã‚‰ã¯å¤§è¦æ¨¡ã§ã€(æ–‡è„ˆä¸Š) åºƒãåˆ©ç”¨å¯èƒ½ã§ã™ã€‚ãã—ã¦ã€æœ¬å½“ã®ä¾¡å€¤ã¯é‰„é“ã‚„é›»åŠ›ç¶²è‡ªä½“ã‹ã‚‰ã§ã¯ãªãã€ãã‚Œã‚‰ã®ä¸Šã«æ§‹ç¯‰ã§ãã‚‹ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã‹ã‚‰ç”Ÿã¾ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚è¨€ã„æ›ãˆã‚‹ã¨ã€ãã‚Œã‚‰ã¯æœ¬è³ªçš„ã«ä¸€è²«æ€§ãŒã‚ã‚Šã€ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ãŒã‚ã‚Šã€éåœ¨çš„ã§ã€åŸºç¤çš„ãªã‚‚ã®ã§ã™ã€‚ã¾ãŸã¯ã€Webster ã®å®šç¾©ã«ã‚ˆã‚Œã°ã€ã€Œä¸‹éƒ¨æ§‹é€ ã¾ãŸã¯åŸºç¤ã¨ãªã‚‹åŸºç›¤ã€‚ç‰¹ã«ã€ã‚³ãƒŸãƒ¥ãƒ‹ãƒ†ã‚£ã€å›½å®¶ãªã©ã®ç¶™ç¶šã¨æˆé•·ãŒä¾å­˜ã™ã‚‹åŸºæœ¬çš„ãªè¨­å‚™ã¨æ–½è¨­ã€ã§ã™ã€‚
ã§ã¯ã€ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã«ã¤ã„ã¦è€ƒãˆã¦ã¿ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒåˆ©ç”¨å¯èƒ½ã«ãªã‚‹å¯èƒ½æ€§ãŒæœ€ã‚‚é«˜ã„æœ€çµ‚æ®µéšã¯ã€ã»ã¨ã‚“ã©ã®äºº (æ¶ˆè²»è€…ã€å¾“æ¥­å“¡ã€å¸‚æ°‘ãªã©) ãŒæºå¸¯é›»è©±ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒã‚¤ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã‹ã‚‰ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã‚’å…¥æ‰‹ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã ã¨ç§ã¯è€ƒãˆã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚å½¼ã‚‰ã¯ã€å…¥æ‰‹ã™ã‚‹ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã«åŸºã¥ã„ã¦ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒã‚¤ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã‚’é¸æŠã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã¯ãªãã€ãã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒã‚¤ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã®ãƒ‡ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ«ãƒˆã®ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã‚’å˜ã«ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ãªãœãªã‚‰ã€å½¼ã‚‰ã¯ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆè‡ªä½“ã®æ©Ÿèƒ½ã«ã¯ã‚ã¾ã‚Šé–¢å¿ƒãŒãªã„ã‹ã‚‰ã§ã™ã€‚å½¼ã‚‰ã¯ã€ã‚¦ã‚©ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆãŒä½¿ã„ã‚„ã™ãã€ä¿¡é ¼æ€§ãŒé«˜ãã€å®‰å…¨ã«å‹•ä½œã—ã€åºƒãå—ã‘å…¥ã‚Œã‚‰ã‚Œã€ãã‚Œã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¦ã•ã¾ã–ã¾ãªãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ã€ç‰©ç†ã€ãƒã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒªãƒƒãƒ‰ ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã«ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ã§ãã‚‹ã“ã¨ã‚’æœ›ã‚“ã§ã„ã‚‹ã ã‘ã§ã™ã€‚
ã“ã®çµæœã¯ã€å®Ÿã¯ç§ãŸã¡å…¨å“¡ã«ã¨ã£ã¦ã®åˆ©ç›Šã§ã™ã€‚å€‹äººã®ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ« ID ã¯ã€ä½¿ã„ã‚„ã™ã•ã€ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚·ãƒ“ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã€ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¯ãƒ«ãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ§ãƒ³ã€é¡§å®¢ç¶­æŒã€ã‚»ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã€ãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒã‚·ãƒ¼ãªã©ã€ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«ç’°å¢ƒã®ã•ã¾ã–ã¾ãªé ˜åŸŸã«é©å‘½ã‚’ã‚‚ãŸã‚‰ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ãã®çµæœã€ä¼æ¥­ã‚„ã€åœ°æ–¹ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã¨å›½å®¶ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã®å…¬å…±ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã‚’å«ã‚€ãã®ä»–ã®å¤§è¦æ¨¡çµ„ç¹”ã«ã€é¡§å®¢ç²å¾—/ç¶­æŒã®å‘ä¸Šã€ã‚»ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã¨ãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒã‚·ãƒ¼ã®ä½“åˆ¶ã®æ”¹å–„ã€ã‚³ã‚¹ãƒˆå‰Šæ¸›ãªã©ã®ãƒ¡ãƒªãƒƒãƒˆãŒã‚‚ãŸã‚‰ã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚

22:30 • 19 days ago

The Pragmatic Engineer

The Pulse #105: More trad tech companies to move off the public cloud?

Also: CockroachDB joins the trend of going from open source to proprietary license, a software glitch nearly floods Amsterdam, and more.

The Pulse is a series covering insights, patterns, and trends within Big Tech and startups. Notice an interesting event or trend? Send me a message.

Today, we cover:

Industry pulse. Microsoft Recall to be unremovable, another â€œAI talent raidâ€ by Amazon, Ticketmaster struggles to handle common load challenges â€“ sometimes, rise and fall of OpenSea, and more.

More trad tech companies to move off public cloud? In a recent report, 83% of chief information officers say they want to move more workload to private clouds. Cloud computing has matured and is becoming more expensive, while private cloud technology is increasingly accessible.

CockroachDB: open source product goes proprietary. Another VC-funded open source product closes itself off, in hope of generating more revenue and profits. Many users need to open their wallets and buy annual licenses, or fork and maintain an older version of CockroachDB.

Software glitch almost floods Amsterdam. Dams near the Dutch capital that were supposed to be closed, mysteriously opened at night during a violent storm. Disaster was averted by a curious employee â€“ and the workaround to avoid similar incidents includes 24-hour human monitoring of dams and water levels.

1. Industry pulse Microsoft Recall to be unremovable

Microsoftâ€™s struggle with its controversial Recall feature continues. Recall is a â€œphotographic memoryâ€ feature planned for Windows 11 which takes constant screenshots of a device, and makes it searchable. Its launch in June was a disaster, as Microsoft skipped basic security and privacy approaches â€“ making these screenshots easily accessible for bad actors. A week after, Microsoft â€œrecalledâ€ Recall, confirming that it will not ship it with these glaring holes.

Now, the Redmond-headquartered tech giant is doubling down on Recall: it will be shipping on Windows 11, and the feature will have no option to be uninstalled. Users wonâ€™t be able to disable it.

The problem with making Recall core to Windows with no way to remove it or turn it off at the OS level, is that it could become a dealbreaker for enterprise clients which will not want an invasive, potentially insecure feature to run on machines by default. Itâ€™s also strange to see Microsoft so set on shipping this feature that is clearly designed to make some use of the hardware GPUs, even though the utility is still questionable. The company will surely keep getting bad press, and privacy-focused techies will have one more reason to stay clear of Windows.

Another â€œAI talent heistâ€

Revisiting the Elm City project

â€œCommunities that want to build comprehensive public calendars will be able to do so using a hybrid approach that blends existing iCalendar feeds with feeds synthesized from web calendars. Itâ€™s not a perfect solution, but with LLM assistance itâ€™s a workable one. And who knows, maybe if people see whatâ€™s possible when information silos converge, â€¦ Continue reading Revisiting the Elm City project

â€œCommunities that want to build comprehensive public calendars will be able to do so using a hybrid approach that blends existing iCalendar feeds with feeds synthesized from web calendars. Itâ€™s not a perfect solution, but with LLM assistance itâ€™s a workable one. And who knows, maybe if people see whatâ€™s possible when information silos converge, the common tools that can ease convergence will seem more attractive.â€ â€” An LLM-Turbocharged Community Calendar Reboot

ãªãŠã€OIXã®åˆ†æã®çµæœã€OIXãŒã€Œãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«IDãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã®DNAã€ã¨ã—ã¦å®šç¾©ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€Œä¸€èˆ¬çš„ãªãƒãƒªã‚·ãƒ¼ãƒ»ãƒ«ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã€ã¨ã€Œã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‡ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ†ã‚£ä¿è¨¼ã«é–¢ã™ã‚‹ãƒãƒªã‚·ãƒ¼ã€ã®2ã¤ã®ä¸»è¦ãƒ†ãƒ¼ãƒã¨ã€é–¢é€£ã™ã‚‹ã‚µãƒ–ãƒ†ãƒ¼ãƒãŒè¨­å®šã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
ã“ã“ã§ã‚‚å°ã‚°ãƒ«ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã«åˆ†ã‹ã‚Œã¦ãƒ‡ã‚£ã‚¹ã‚«ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’è¡Œã„ã€ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã®è¦ç´ ã‚’ç”¨ã„ã¦å„å›½ã®çŠ¶æ³ã®åˆ†æã‚’è¡Œã£ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ è©³ç´°ã¯ãƒ¬ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚’è¦‹ã¦ã„ãŸã ã‘ã‚Œã°ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ãŒã€ã“ã‚“ãªæ„Ÿã˜ã§åˆ†æã—ãŸã‚ˆã†ã§ã™ã€‚

ã¾ãŸã€ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã®ãƒ™ãƒãƒ•ã‚£ãƒƒãƒˆã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã‚‚è­°è«–ãŒè¡Œã‚ã‚Œã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ çµæœã€ä»¥ä¸‹ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªã¾ã¨ã‚ãŒè¡Œã‚ã‚ŒãŸã¨ã®ã“ã¨ã§ã™ã€‚ ã“ã®åˆ†æã®ãƒ™ãƒãƒ•ã‚£ãƒƒãƒˆ ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ã®æ¨é€² ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ä¿è­·ã¨ã‚»ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã®ä¿ƒé€² ã‚³ã‚¹ãƒˆã®å‰Šæ¸› åŒ…æ‘‚ ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«çµŒæ¸ˆã®ç™ºå±• å®˜æ°‘ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã®æä¾›ã¸ã®å¿—å‘ ä¸€æ–¹ã§ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¬ãƒ³ã‚¸ã¨ã—ã¦ä»¥ä¸‹ã‚‚æŒ™ã’ã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ ãƒãƒªã‚·ãƒ¼ã‚’ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«é‹ç”¨ã—ã¦ã„ãã‹ ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«åŒ–ã‚’ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«é€²ã‚ã‚‹ã‹ äººçš„è¦å› ãƒ»ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ­åŒ–ãƒ»ãƒªãƒ¼ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒƒãƒ—ã®èª²é¡Œã¸ã®å¯¾å¿œ ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã®ä¸è¶³ ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ«ä¸è¶³ åœ°ç†çš„ãªå•é¡Œã€è¦æ¨¡ã€ã‚»ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ä¸Šã®å•é¡Œ ãã—ã¦ã€ä½•ãŒè¶³ã‚Šãªã„ã®ã‹ï¼Ÿã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã‚‚è­°è«–ãŒè¡Œã‚ã‚Œã€ã€Œå°‚é–€å®¶ã®ã‚¢ãƒ‰ãƒã‚¤ã‚¹ã®ä¸­ç«‹æ€§ã‚’ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«æ‹…ä¿ãƒ»ç¢ºèªã™ã‚‹ã®ã‹ï¼Ÿã€ãªã©ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã‚‚èªã‚‰ã‚ŒãŸã‚ˆã†ã§ã™ã€‚ã©ã†ã‚„ã‚‰ä¸€éƒ¨ã®å›½ã®æ”¿åºœã¯å¤–éƒ¨æœ‰è­˜è€…ã¸ã®ã‚¢ãƒ‰ãƒã‚¤ã‚¹ã‚’æ±‚ã‚ã‚‹éš›ã€å…¬å¹³æ€§ã‚„ä¸­ç«‹æ€§ã«èª²é¡ŒãŒã‚ã‚‹ã€ã¨è€ƒãˆã‚‹ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã‚‚ã‚ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ã§ã™ã€‚

ãªãŠã€ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã®è­°è«–ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã‚‚UNHCRã¨ã®é–¢é€£ã§è­°è«–ãŒè¡Œã‚ã‚Œã¾ã—ãŸã€‚
Meanwhile, non-jurisdictions focused on how to support UNHCR, which has the challenge of serving 130M current refugees that are part of the UNHCR system and under their protection. They have integrations with about 7 strategic partners including refugee origin and destination countries, and they need to have 50-60 more integrations to national civil registry systems. Some users entering the system will have documents from their origin country and the origin country system of record may be accessible to check data against and people may have mobile devices (e.g. Ukraine), while other individuals may not have mobile devices and may be stateless or originate from failed states where records are not available.

ä¸€æ–¹ã€éç®¡è½„å½“å±€ã¯ã€UNHCRã‚’ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«æ”¯æ´ã™ã‚‹ã‹ã«ç„¦ç‚¹ã‚’å½“ã¦ãŸã€‚UNHCRã¯ã€UNHCRã®ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã®ä¸€éƒ¨ã§ã‚ã‚Šã€ãã®ä¿è­·ã®ä¸‹ã«ã‚ã‚‹1å„„3,000ä¸‡äººã®ç¾åœ¨ã®é›£æ°‘ã«ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã‚’æä¾›ã™ã‚‹ã¨ã„ã†èª²é¡Œã‚’æŠ±ãˆã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚UNHCRã¯ã€é›£æ°‘ã®å‡ºèº«å›½ã‚„ç›®çš„åœ°ã‚’å«ã‚€ç´„7ã®æˆ¦ç•¥çš„ãƒ‘ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒŠãƒ¼ã¨çµ±åˆã—ã¦ãŠã‚Šã€ã•ã‚‰ã«50ï½60ã®å›½åˆ¥å¸‚æ°‘ç™»éŒ²ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¨ã®çµ±åˆãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã‚ã‚‹ã€‚ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«å…¥ã‚‹åˆ©ç”¨è€…ã®ä¸­ã«ã¯ã€å‡ºèº«å›½ã®æ–‡æ›¸ã‚’æŒã£ã¦ã„ã¦ã€ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚’ç…§åˆã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«å‡ºèº«å›½ã®è¨˜éŒ²ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã«ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ã§ããŸã‚Šã€æºå¸¯ç«¯æœ«ã‚’æŒã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹äººï¼ˆã‚¦ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒŠãªã©ï¼‰ãŒã„ã‚‹ä¸€æ–¹ã§ã€æºå¸¯ç«¯æœ«ã‚’æŒã£ã¦ãŠã‚‰ãšã€ç„¡å›½ç±ã§ã‚ã£ãŸã‚Šã€è¨˜éŒ²ãŒåˆ©ç”¨ã§ããªã„ç ´ç¶»å›½å®¶å‡ºèº«ã§ã‚ã£ãŸã‚Šã™ã‚‹äººã‚‚ã„ã‚‹ã€‚ 

æ•°å¤šãã®é›£æ°‘ã‚’æ”¯æ´ã™ã‚‹UNHCRã§ã¯å¤šãã®å›½ã®ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¨ã®ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ã‚’å®Ÿç¾ã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚Šãã†ã§ã™ã€‚ã—ã‹ã—ãªãŒã‚‰é›£æ°‘ã®çŠ¶æ³ã¯ã•ã¾ã–ã¾ãªã®ã§å›½æ°‘IDã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¸ã®ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ãŒã§ããªã„å ´åˆãªã©ã‚‚ã‚ã‚‹ã®ã§éå¸¸ã«é›£ã—ã„èˆµå–ã‚ŠãŒæ±‚ã‚ã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹çŠ¶æ…‹ã®ã‚ˆã†ã§ã™ã€‚

ã¾ãŸã‚¦ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒŠã®çŠ¶æ³ã‚’ä¾‹ã¨ã—ã¦UNHCRã«ä½•ãŒæ±‚ã‚ã‚‰ã‚Œã‚‹ã®ã‹ï¼Ÿã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã‚‚è­°è«–ãŒè¡Œã‚ã‚Œã€é›£æ°‘ç™»éŒ²ã‚„ãƒ‡ã‚¸ã‚¿ãƒ«æŠ€è¡“ã«ã‚ˆã‚‹è§£æ±ºãªã©ã‚‚è©±é¡Œã«ä¸Šã£ãŸã‚ˆã†ã§ã™ã€‚


ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã§ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã®ã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚‚çµ‚ã‚ã‚Šã§ã™ã€‚

æ¬¡å›ã¯ã‚¬ãƒãƒŠãƒ³ã‚¹ã§ã™ã€‚




 





22:30 • 21 days ago

Michael Ruminer

My Failed (so far) AI RAG Code Experimentation

I have been wanting to experiment with creating some code performing retrieval augmented generation (RAG) for an LLM. So far I am 0 for 2. In both examples I tried, that were professed to work, it fell far short. I blame embedding and retrieval. I also blame myselfâ€¦ who else is there to blame. I know RAG works in some form because I can go onto ChatGPT upload a PDF and prompt about it with expecte

I have been wanting to experiment with creating some code performing retrieval augmented generation (RAG) for an LLM. So far I am 0 for 2. In both examples I tried, that were professed to work, it fell far short. I blame embedding and retrieval. I also blame myselfâ€¦ who else is there to blame. I know RAG works in some form because I can go onto ChatGPT upload a PDF and prompt about it with expected and quality results; but, when trying to replicate similar outcomes from code and the OpenAI API I get disappointing results. Hereâ€™s the story.

Experiment one was part of a Udemy course on RAG and mastering some better approaches than naive RAG. Specifically RAG with query expansion. It was a very short course but had a couple of cohesive Python examples that built out over the course material. It included the document to use for the augmentation. Additionally, unlike experiment two, it largely didnâ€™t rely on a ton of abstraction of the underlying basic concepts. After reading and parsing the text from the PDF I used RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter and
SentenceTransformersTokenTextSplitter from Langchain to create my chunks. Added my chunks to Chroma db in memory using their default embedder. Took my query and performed the retrieval of 5 chunks from the Chroma db. No reranking performed. The returned chunks were at best partial results and at worst just not as good as expected. What I hadnâ€™t noticed about the code from the instruction when I went through the class is that it never passed the chunks back as context to the LLM the second time along with the query to get an answer. Kind of an important part to be missing. I can tell from the returned chunks it would not have produced a satisfactory answer had the closing action before performed. I tried with differing chunk sizes and overlaps and never received better results. I tried with my own document and faired no better. I chalked it up to a disappointing and poor example. Perhaps this is why it didnâ€™t go the final step to pass it all back to the LLM for a response.

I moved on to a second experiment that used a bit more abstraction by relying on Langchain significantly more. It was also doing naive RAG, not augmenting the prompt from the LLM initially in any way. This time it did have the pass to the LLM in the end to get the LLM response. Looking at the chunks it retrieved I could tell I wasnâ€™t going to get a satisfactory response. I had asked it for a list of 10 principles that were specifically outlined in the document in a single paragraph. The best in all my attempts was that I got 2, maybe 3 of the list. Again I played around with chunk size and overlap and generally only got worse results. The results in the demonstration had not seemed much better when I evaluated it more closely.

All in all I need a third+ experiment. I am trying to get a response even remotely similar to what I get from the ChatGPT. Obviously, my examples are not high enough quality.

Do you have such an example?

Time to ask ChatGPT, Claude, Github Copliot, or Cursorâ€Šâ€”â€Šsounds like a job for Cursorâ€Šâ€”â€Što create a python program for me and see how it functions.

19:17 • 21 days ago

The Pragmatic Engineer

Paying down tech debt

A guide for reducing tech debt effectively, and how to develop a mindset that welcomes the short-term benefits of eliminating it. A guest post by principal engineer Lou Franco
Q: â€œIâ€™d like to make a better case for paying down tech debt on my team. What are some proven approaches for this?â€

The tension in finding the right balance between shipping features and paying down accumulated tech debt is as old as software engineering. Thereâ€™s no one answer on how best to reduce tech debt, and opinion is divided about whether zero tech debt is even a good thing to aim for. But approaches for doing it exist which work well for most teams.

To tackle this eternal topic, I turned to industry veteran Lou Franco, whoâ€™s been in the software business for over 30 years as an engineer, EM, and executive. Heâ€™s also worked at four startups and the companies that later acquired them; most recently Atlassian as a Principal Engineer on the Trello iOS app. 

Heâ€™s currently an operating partner at private equity firm SilverTree Equity, and technical co-founder at a new startup. Lou says he isnâ€™t delighted about the volume of tech debt accumulated during his career, but is satisfied with how much of it heâ€™s managed to pay down. 

In this guest post, Lou shares insights about how to approach tech debt. Later this year, heâ€™s publishing a book on the subject. For updates on this upcoming release, subscribe here.

In this article, we cover:

Pay down tech debt to go faster, now. Itâ€™s common for less experienced engineering leaders to assume that focusing on features and ignoring tech debt is how to move faster. Lou used to agree, but not any more.

Use tech debt to boost productivity. Three examples of when tackling tech debt empowered engineering teams to move faster, right away.

Link tech debt and value delivery. When tech debt is tackled sensibly, it delivers business value. At Trello and Atalasoft, this was how Lou got engineers and management to appreciate the task.

Make tech debtâ€™s effects visible. Dashboards are an effective way to visualize the impact of tech debt. A few examples.

Factor in time saved when thinking about productivity. Reducing tech debt typically improves coding, reviewing, and deployment for everyone.

Use tech debt payments to get into the flow. In a counter-intuitive observation: by making small, non-functional improvements, you gain more confidence in a new codebase, and can start to move faster.

Big rewrites need heavyweight support. Without the backing of management, a large-scale rewrite is likely to fail.

With that, itâ€™s over to Lou:

1. Pay down tech debt to go faster immediately

What is tech debt?

I define tech debt as any problem in the codebase that affects programmers by making it harder to make necessary changes. As a programmer, I wanted to fix such issues because they slowed me down. But as a manager, I had to ensure the team delivered value to stakeholders. Iâ€™ve gone back and forth between these roles during my career, and made mistakes in both directions â€“ but I also learned a lot about getting the balance right.

Reducing tech debt pays off immediately in faster builds

In 2010, I was head of development at Atalasoft, a company in the .NET developer tools space. I was obsessed with shipping, and spent all my time worrying about delivering the features in our roadmap. Over time, we improved at this, which showed up in our revenue growth and eventually led to an acquisition. 

We were in a competitive market with more opportunities than we could handle. We had fewer than ten developers, but we were bootstrapped, so had to stay profitable and couldnâ€™t just hire ahead of revenue.

The stakes got even higher after we were acquired. We had two years to deliver on an ambitious roadmap, for which there was an earnout bonus contingent upon delivery. If we didnâ€™t deliver, weâ€™d likely be classified as a failed acquisition. Our new owners had just had one such failure, which led to downsizing and an office closure.

My mindset was that any time spent on technical debt meant weâ€™d fail to deliver on the roadmap. We couldnâ€™t risk the deadline by wasting time cleaning up old messes, and had to choose between tech debt and roadmap delivery. In hindsight, I see this was wrong. I learned that the mindset of ignoring tech debt hurt my team.

Following an exit interview in which a departing engineer mentioned tech debt had contributed to their decision to leave, I started asking people during 1:1s how they felt about it. Their responses showed their frustration with me. 

By then, I had been a developer for over fifteen years, and had worked in codebases with a lot of debt, so I knew what it was like. But by now, I was a manager who sometimes contributed code, but had forgotten what it was like to be thwarted by the codebase every day. To my team, I was part of the problem. They had been trying to tell me this, but I didnâ€™t get it. Their departing colleague with nothing to lose in their exit interview finally got through to me and helped me understand the depth of the issue, and that it was slowing everyone down.

I learned an important lesson: the cost of tech debt is borne daily by your team, and you risk damaging motivation and raising attrition by ignoring it. Even if you have every reason to move forward without addressing tech debt, being an empathic manager requires you at least do something. Doing nothing â€“ like I did â€“ is not a good option.

So we started making changes. The biggest problems were with our build system and installer because they affected every developer and every product. It was a tangled bag of legacy code that needed constant maintenance, but it wasnâ€™t very big, and I approved a plan to rewrite it with modern tools. It was a small experiment but paid off right away in quicker CI builds and an easier-to-modify codebase. Most importantly, I saw it didnâ€™t derail our roadmap, so we took on other small initiatives.

This taught me another lesson about addressing technical debt. I had thought of it as something that might pay off in the long run. Might. This belief made it hard to justify doing it when I had to deliver on short-term goals. But instead, something else happened:

We paid off tech debt and increased productivity instantly! We had a build with faster feedback loops, less cognitive load, and which didnâ€™t make developers frustrated when they had to add to it, which happened regularly. Updates were made with less code and without breaking things. It was an example of tech debt reduction paying off in increased developer productivity, right away.

Learning the cost of too much rewriting at Trello

I got my next lesson at Trello where I worked on the iOS app. The codebase was three years old when I joined in 2014. It had understandable tech debt because they needed to move fast, after going from 0 to 6 million sign ups. The devs working on it were founding engineers, working as described by The Pragmatic Engineer in Thriving as a Founding Engineer, and seeking product-market fit. Our biggest tech debt issue were some frameworks that made it fast to build a simple app, but held us back as the app got more complex.

Our own choices were influenced by the speed of Appleâ€™s updates to iOS. The iOS 7 update completely changed the iOS design language and its network APIs. Later, iOS 8 introduced presentation controllers that gave developers much control over the animation when new views are shown. Unfortunately, the iOS 8 change broke our navigation code and caused crashes. These added up and started to make our code seem antiquated.

Left: how most iOS 6 apps looked like. Right: the iOS 7 version. iOS 7 introduced a â€˜flatterâ€™ look, and required lots of code changes to implement this new UI. Screenshot is from my app called Habits

Our code got even more complex when Apple decided to feature Trello on physical iPhones at Apple Stores. To be in stores, we needed a build that worked without an account or a network, so a mock backend was embedded in it for demo purposes. We didnâ€™t want to maintain a separate codebase, so had a lot of random bits of demo-mode logic that stayed for years. 

At Trello, I was coding every day and all this was in my face. Luckily, we were a small team of three developers, so my direct manager was also coding every day and was empathetic to the problems.

We did rewrites as we went, but sometimes went too far. To deal with the presentation controller problem of iOS 8, we developed a new paradigm for screen navigation inside the app, and rewrote all navigation to use it. This approach was the exact opposite of what I did at Atalasoft, where Iâ€™d ignored all tech debt. 

Unfortunately, the approach of rewriting early turned out to be overkill. In hindsight, we could have just corrected the places that had crashed, and then lived with the code we had. Instead, we spent a few months designing and implementing a new, non-standard way of writing navigation code, but forgot a vital lesson that one of our founders, Joel Spolsky, identified in 2000 in Things You Should Never Do:

â€œWeâ€™re programmers. Programmers are, in their hearts, architects, and the first thing they want to do when they get to a site is to bulldoze the place flat and build something grand. Weâ€™re not excited by incremental renovation: tinkering, improving, planting flower beds.

Thereâ€™s a subtle reason that programmers always want to throw away the code and start over. The reason is that they think the old code is a mess. And here is the interesting observation: they are probably wrong. The reason that they think the old code is a mess is because of a cardinal, fundamental law of programming:

Itâ€™s harder to read code than to write it.â€

On the Trello engineering team, we were all very familiar with this article and quoted it to each other often, but it still sometimes bit us. The urge to rewrite a system instead of fixing it is strong, and we couldnâ€™t resist! We should have addressed the few complex navigation cases that crashed our code without the full rewrite.

Size tech debt payment to be proportional to value. This is the biggest lesson I learned on this project.

Iâ€™ve seen both extremes of dealing with tech debt:

As a manager, I was overly resistant to devoting time to dealing with technical debt

As an engineer, I was exposed to its problems every day and didnâ€™t resist the urge to pay it off enough 

These two extremes form the fundamental tension of dealing with tech debt. As usual, there needs to be a balance, but finding it is not so easy. 

The heuristic I use to pay tech debt these days is this: by reducing a specific tech debt, can I increase developer productivity and deliver business value right now?

If I canâ€™t, then I donâ€™t pay it down. 

When the debt is so big that it couldnâ€™t possibly deliver value now, or the value is invisible so nobody sees it, I do something else. Let me break down my heuristicâ€¦

2. Use tech debt to increase productivity

I try to pay down a little bit of tech debt regularly by making small cleanup commits as I go. I started doing this more intentionally after reading Kent Beckâ€™s book, Extreme Programming Explained, in 1999, which introduced me to automated unit tests and continuous integration. Then, when I read Martin Fowlerâ€™s Refactoring, I started to see how to improve a codebase over time with very small, behavior-preserving changes checked by unit tests. In both books, and in others like Working Effectively with Legacy Code by Michael Feathers, and Kent Beckâ€™s recent, Tidy First?, the authors stress that technical debt is inevitable, and that the main way to curtail it is to be constantly fixing it with small improvements enabled by unit tests and mechanical refactoring. I agree.

Unit tests, refactoring, and continuous integration are ubiquitous in the kinds of software I write, which are B2B SaaS productivity applications. Even making small improvements on an ongoing basis is common among my coworkers. It doesnâ€™t take long, and there are usually quick wins to be had, like making the code more readable, or using a unit test to show how the code is supposed to work. Even in frontend code, Trello iOS adopted Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) so we could test view-logic. We got the immediate productivity benefit of being able to run view code repeatedly without needing to manipulate a running app through several screens to check that our changes worked.

The issue is when the debt is large, which is where I struggled. My problem at Atalasoft was not with small improvements; it was with the bigger ones where Iâ€™d have to trade off current benefits like delivering features for the roadmap, for uncertain future benefits.

But I realized something.

You can get productivity benefits immediately, even with larger initiatives. If you do it right, you will deliver feature work faster and with higher quality. In fact, I view tech debt proposals that donâ€™t deliver instant developer productivity gains as suspect. 

Rewriting the build and installer at Atalasoft brought an immediate productivity boost. We had a backlog of problems and new additions, but the rewrite took one developer around a month, and when it was done many of the problems just went away because the new system was based on a framework wherein many problems could not occur, meaning we could close a bunch of reported bugs. The new system was unit testable, so we didnâ€™t need to build and install the entire system during development to test our new changes while we were writing it. We also got more benefits later, but the instant benefits justified it.

At Trello, adding unit tests to a codebase helped me finish a project faster. When I joined in 2014, we were just about to start our internationalization (i18n) project, which I took on for the iOS app. One part was to write support for i18n-safe string interpolation (inserting variables or expressions into a string,) and pluralization (adjusting words to plural forms based on the number they refer to, to make the phrases grammatically correct) â€“ which was only partially supported in iOS at the time. Itâ€™s standard string manipulation at its core, but in 2014 our iOS app didnâ€™t have unit tests.

Without unit tests, if I had wanted to run the code, Iâ€™d need to run the app and then tap-tap-tap until I got to a specific string. I would have to do this for each kind of string I generated. But with unit-tests, I could just list all the examples with their expected results, and run tests in less than a second. So, I proposed to the team to add unit tests to our build and CI.

No one was against unit tests, but it hadnâ€™t been a priority. Most of the code was UI or network code, for which unit tests are harder to write. But the code I was writing was highly testable, and in fact, itâ€™s harder to write without tests. So, I added the unit test project to our workspace and wrote the string code. With the unit test project there, the other developers added tests to their work. I was there for six more years, and saw the benefits of the tests over time, especially in complex code like our sync engine. But thatâ€™s not why I did it: I added the unit tests to go faster immediately.

Also at Trello, creating an abstraction layer for the design system made us more productive. Eventually, we created a design system with a reduced set of fonts, colors, and other design attributes and specific rules for using them. Before, it was common to see hardcoded values in view controllers throughout the app, as each screen implemented the designerâ€™s specification for that screen, which wasnâ€™t always consistent. We could have just updated those lines to the new approved values, but it was the perfect time to make an abstraction for the design system itself. Doing this made it faster to write code that matched a design, and when a default in the design system changed, it would be reflected everywhere.

These three examples also adhere to another heuristic I use for finding the right balance with tech debt: coupling it with delivery of value.

3. Couple tech debt fixes with value delivery

Read more

18:56 • 21 days ago

Patrick Breyer

Chatkontrolle-Blitzentscheidung? Ungarn will beispiellose PlÃ¤ne der EU zur Messenger-MassenÃ¼berwachung doch noch durchsetzen

Schon morgen frÃ¼h sollen die EU-Regierungen den umstrittenen Gesetzentwurf zur Chatkontrolle, der im Juni nach massiven Protesten von der Tagesordnung genommen wurde, jetzt doch unterstÃ¼tzen. Erreichen will die neue ungarische â€¦

Schon morgen frÃ¼h sollen die EU-Regierungen den umstrittenen Gesetzentwurf zur Chatkontrolle, der im Juni nach massiven Protesten von der Tagesordnung genommen wurde, jetzt doch unterstÃ¼tzen. Erreichen will die neue ungarische RatsprÃ¤sidentschaft dies nach einer Meldung des Nachrichtendienstes Contexte mit einer von Politico geleakten DetailÃ¤nderung, nÃ¤mlich dem Verzicht auf die besonders fehleranfÃ¤llige Suche nach unbekanntem Material im Zuge der verpflichtenden Chatkontrolle (freiwillig soll sie mÃ¶glich bleiben). Geplant bleibt aber ansonsten die automatisierte Durchsuchung und gegebenenfalls Ausleitung privater Chats, darunter auch Ende-zu-Ende-verschlÃ¼sselte Chats, die zuvor klassifizierte verdÃ¤chtige Fotos oder Videos enthalten sollen. Lehnt ein Nutzer diese â€Upload-Moderationâ€œ seiner Chats ab, kÃ¶nnte er keinerlei Bilder, Videos oder URLs mehr senden oder empfangen. Signal und Threema haben angekÃ¼ndigt, dass sie ihre Dienste in der EU einstellen wÃ¼rden, wenn sie gezwungen wÃ¼rden, die vorgeschlagene automatisierte MassenÃ¼berwachung (sogenanntes â€Client-Side Scanningâ€œ) umzusetzen.

Der ehemalige Europaabgeordnete der Piratenpartei, Patrick Breyer, ruft die BÃ¼rger jetzt dazu auf sich an die EU-Regierungen zu wenden: â€Im Juni gab es unter massivem Ã¶ffentlichen Druck noch eine hauchdÃ¼nne SperrminoritÃ¤t zur Rettung des Digitalen Briefgeheimnisses, aber kaum bemerkte Blitzaktionen, zwischenzeitliche Regierungswechsel und MinimalzugestÃ¤ndnisse kÃ¶nnen das schnell Ã¤ndern. Falls die Chatkontrolle kommt, werden wir gÃ¤ngige sichere Messenger ganz einfach nicht mehr nutzen kÃ¶nnen â€“ das bedeutet wir verlieren den Kontakt zu unseren Freunden und Kollegen in der ganzen Weltâ€œ, warnt Breyer. â€Wollen wir wirklich, dass Europa weltweit fÃ¼hrend beim AbhÃ¶ren unserer Smartphones und der flÃ¤chendeckenden Ãœberwachung der Chats von Millionen gesetzestreuer BÃ¼rger wird? Das EuropÃ¤ische Parlament ist Ã¼berzeugt, dass diese orwellsche Chatkontrolle das dringliche Anliegen eines besseren Kinder- und Opferschutzes verrÃ¤t, weil sie unweigerlich vor Gericht scheitern wird. Es fordert deshalb einen wirklich wirksamen Kinderschutz durch sicherere Apps, proaktive SÃ¤uberung des Internets und eine Pflicht zur LÃ¶schung illegaler Inhalte â€“ nichts davon ist in dem dem neuesten Orban-VorstoÃŸ vorgesehen, zu dem sich die Regierungen morgen positionieren sollen. Jetzt liegt es an uns ihn zu stoppen!â€œ

Die Chatkontrolle auf vermeintlich â€bekannteâ€œ illegale Inhalte beschrÃ¤nken zu wollen, bezeichnet Breyer als Augenwischerei: â€Egal mit welchem Ziel â€“ auch die Post darf nicht einfach jeden Brief verdachtslos Ã¶ffnen und durchschnÃ¼ffeln. Gerade die von US-Konzernen schon heute freiwillig praktizierte Durchleuchtung nach vermeintlich bekannten Inhalten fÃ¼hrt zur Ausleitung tausender vÃ¶llig legaler privater Chats, zur Ãœberlastung der Strafverfolger und zur massenhaften Kriminalisierung MinderjÃ¤hriger. MassenÃ¼berwachung ohne jeden Anlass zerstÃ¶rt das digitale Briefgeheimnis und sichere VerschlÃ¼sselung, auf die wir alle und auch unsere Kinder dringend angewiesen sind.â€œ

ä»Šå›ã¯å„ã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’è¦‹ã¦ã¿ãŸã„ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

SIDI Summit Introduction - å ±å‘Šè€…ï¼šElizabeth Garber

ã¾ãšã¯Elizabethã‹ã‚‰ã€SIAã®StephanieãŒæ‹…å½“ã—ãŸæœ€åˆã®ã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã«é–¢ã—ã¦å ±å‘Šã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

SIDI is delighted to be at ID4Africa because the concept was born at an ID4Africa discussion about the development of national identity schemes with vastly different architectures â€“ centralized, decentralized â€“ and different models of governance. The SIDI organizers sought to promote discussions of interoperability between those systems to ensure that no nations are left behind as interoperability is established across others.

SIDI ã¯ ID4Africa ã«å‚åŠ ã§ãã‚‹ã“ã¨ã‚’å–œã°ã—ãæ€ã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚ã¨ã„ã†ã®ã‚‚ã€ã“ã®ã‚³ãƒ³ã‚»ãƒ—ãƒˆã¯ã€ID4Africa ã®ãƒ‡ã‚£ã‚¹ã‚«ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã§ã€ä¸­å¤®é›†æ¨©å‹ã€åœ°æ–¹åˆ†æ¨©å‹ãªã©ã€ã‚¢ãƒ¼ã‚­ãƒ†ã‚¯ãƒãƒ£ãŒå¤§ããç•°ãªã‚Šã€çµ±æ²»ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã‚‚ç•°ãªã‚‹å›½å®¶ ID ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ¼ãƒ ã®é–‹ç™ºã«ã¤ã„ã¦è­°è«–ã™ã‚‹ä¸­ã§ç”Ÿã¾ã‚ŒãŸã‹ã‚‰ã§ã‚ã‚‹ã€‚SIDI ã®ä¸»å‚¬è€…ã¯ã€ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ãŒä»–å›½é–“ã§ç¢ºç«‹ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ä¸­ã§ã€å–ã‚Šæ®‹ã•ã‚Œã‚‹å›½ãŒãªã„ã‚ˆã†ã«ã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã€ã“ã‚Œã‚‰ã®ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ é–“ã®ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ã®è­°è«–ã‚’ä¿ƒé€²ã—ã‚ˆã†ã¨ã—ãŸã€‚

ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¿ã‚¦ãƒ³é–‹å‚¬ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã‚‚ã‚ã‚ŠID4Africaã¨ã®å”æ¥­ã«ã¤ã„ã¦è§¦ã‚Œã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚å‰å›ã‚‚è§¦ã‚Œã¾ã—ãŸãŒã€ã‚¢ãƒ•ãƒªã‚«ã¨ã„ã†åœ°åŸŸç‰¹æ€§ã€çµ±æ²»ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã€å›½æ°‘IDã®ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ¼ãƒ ã®ä¸­ã§ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«ç›¸äº’é‹ç”¨æ€§ã‚’å®Ÿç¾ã™ã‚‹ã®ã‹ã¯éå¸¸ã«é‡è¦ãªã“ã¨ã ã¨æ€ã‚ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ãã—ã¦ã“ã®ãƒ†ãƒ¼ãƒã¯UNDPï¼ˆå›½é€£é–‹ç™ºãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒ ï¼‰ã®é–¢å¿ƒã”ã¨ã®ä¸€ã¤ã§ã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã—ã€æ—¥æœ¬æ”¿åºœï¼ˆå¤–å‹™çœï¼‰ã‹ã‚‰UNDPã¸ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ãƒ³ãƒ‰ãŒæ‹ å‡ºã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹åˆ†é‡ã§ã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã®è¾ºã‚Šã¯æ—¥æœ¬ã‹ã‚‰ã‚‚ã£ã¨æ”¯æ´ãŒã§ãã‚‹ã¨è‰¯ã„ã¨æ€ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

ã¾ãŸã€åŒæ™‚ã«Introductionã‚»ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã‚‚ã‚ã‚Šã€SIDI Hubã®æˆ¦ç•¥ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ç´¹ä»‹ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
